Lethal League is one of the most intense dodgeball type games I've seen in my life. Maybe even THE most intense. This game makes it so the ball goes really fast. And I mean FAST. The maximum speed a ball can get to is 10,000. That is ridiculous. The characters are all very enjoyable too. The aim is to get the most points or be the last one standing. When you hit someone with the ball, they go flying across the screen and off it. The characters play pretty much the same, but with different special moves. Raptor's baseball bat can send the ball going straight forward, Switch's kick flip can make the ball move weirdly and confuse players, Candyman can confuse the player by sending the ball across the screen and looping to the other side of it, Sonata's bass drop can give the ball extra speed, Latch can eat the ball and spit it out whenever he wants, and Dice's curve shot can send the ball flying in weird angles. If the ball gets enough speed, the stage can noticeably change. That's kind of a tough to notice detail, but it's cool.

Overall it's a crazy dodgeball fighting game. The ball goes everywhere, crazy attacks can be performed, and people go flying off the screen. That's why my final rating for this game is a Super Smash Bros. out of 10. (Want a real rating? 8 out of 10.)
It is a great game but the thing that is missing is that the is not that mutch characters but everything else is perfect.

But after leaving it to gather dust in my library for a few months, I decided I wanted to go back to it. But I booted up the game and, no matter what graphics settings it was set to, the game only ran at a maximum of 25 fps. Other than that, the game is great. By the way, if you happen to have a fix for the fps problem, it'd be greatly appreciated.

A strange combination of Smash Bros and Dodgeball, Lethal League is a fast paced fighting game revolving around smacking balls at speeds of up to a million miles per hour right into your opponents noggin. Simple, but elegant.

Let me start off by saying that this is more of a party game then a full fledged fighter or anything.  That's the beauty of Lethal League though is it aims to keep the fun simple with a delightful mechanic and well animated and imaginative characters and music.  Here are my lists of Pros and Cons by Catagory 

Gameplay- Pros:  This game is fast paced and has a mechanic revolving around a ball that kills upon impact from another player's succesful swing and hit.  the object of the game is to knock out the other fighters ala super smash bros or other arcade fighters by smashing the ball their way in hopes that they will not have the reaction time to swing back and be slammed out of the arena.  The gameplay is fast and addictive and best experienced with friends and is highly based on reaction time and the ability to angle the ball or juke other players with the "bunt" function or special hits that build up as you hit/bunt the ball.  In short it's a fun arcadey baseball deathmatch game with a simple but unique mechanic.

Gameplay-  Cons:  The single player "challenge" mode(this games version of super smash bros's classic mode) leaves much to be desired and is quite simple, and while the ai can be challennging for a new player at first it is never as difficult as a real player leaving multiplayer the best option.  There are multiple game modes but most players seldom use or even have fun with them, and the game could use more content on the single player and gameplay mode selection side overall.  

Graphics- Pros:  The art style and characters are lovingly inspired from a variety of sources most notably I see hints of super smash bros characters and jetset radio style stlye.  You have a baseball loving tough kid, a woman that uses a boombox on a stick as a bat, a man with a piece of candy for a head, and a cyborg alligator, and a robot(who uses a skateboard as his bat and means to get around), and a man named Dice...who oddly enough uses a ping pong paddle.  The art is lovingly design and the stages and characters have a lot of personality

Graphics- Cons:  The characters could use a few more animation touch ups and overall new animations I'd argue and the art style is sometimes used to cover up what is a seemingly simple engine, the stages could use some work too and I feel some of them while inspired could use even more touchups and design changes both aesthetically, and gameplay wise(they are all essentially boxes)


Music/Audio- Pros:  This is where the game really shines in the music department.  If you enjoyed Jetset Radio at all you will feel more then welcome and at home here then you have in a game since that series.  The music is incredibly well done and produced and I'll sometimes find myself wanting to play certain stages in the game just to hear the tunes.  "Ordinary Days" is a personal favorite of mine though all the tracks of each stage and menu are seething with excellent production and unique "garage future" tones.

Music Audio- Cons:  The characters are lacking in some voice overs and you'll often hear the same voice clips over and over again.  This is not all bad as some lines are quite clever but I really wish the dev team would give them a bit more life with some new and alternate lines.
----
   Overall the game is pretty fun if you have some buddies itching for some crazy arcadey multiplayer.  It can get pretty intense as the ball speed ramps up higher and higher until the stages are tearing at the seams.  I don't recommend purchasing it at full price however, I would wait for a price drop or a sale to pick this rad, lovable, indie arcade fighter in the future.

I found this really interesting game on YouTube, and it looked appealing. So I waited for a good sale, bought it, and just had a blast. When I first saw this game, I thought it was your average fighting game that you could land all the sweet combos with friends. But Lethal League is so much more than just a fighting game. With the only way to blast fighters out of the arena using a ball that is consitantly gaining speed, bouncing, flying, and who knows what in any direction, this game adds an intense factor in trying to stay alive.

I remember when I had three friends over and we all had out own wired controllers, so I suggested we played Lethal League. I had already been playing a lot of it, and they had never played in their life. Now, when I thought playing alone was fun, I never accounted having friends to play with. But when more people joined the game, it becomes hilariously joyous, with a lot of tense moments of only two people left and the ball being at over 1000 speed, some people figuring out new attacks, or people getting that three-hit wipeout, mostly on accident.

All in all, Lethal League is a sweat-inducing and creative game, bringing a fresh idea to the fighting game genre, and one that works incredibly well. The multiplayer works great, hit detection is fine, the characters are interesting, and the gameplay is just plain awesome.
Delievers what it promises in an exciting and fun way, though what it promises could be more.

... Oh, right. I'm writing a review. Here's my pros and cons list if you don't want to read the rest of my review.
[list]
[b]Pros:[/b]
[*] Fast-paced high-intensity gameplay that only increases in speed and intensity as the match goes on
[*] Beginner-friendly with an optional tutorial that can be replayed as many times as needed, as well as a practice mode
[*] 6 characters to choose from with unlockable character colors the more you play
[*] Online and local multiplayer supports up to 4 players
[*] Free-for-all and Team Battle game modes
[*] Single player campaign mode available (and achievements for beating it with each character)
[*] Gameplay is fluent and customizable with either keyboard or controller, controlled with 3 buttons outside the four directional movement buttons
[*] Amazing Soundtrack (at least, I think so)
[b]Cons:[/b]
[*] Lethal League online translates to Lethal Lag; I'd recommend not playing online if you and your friends do not have a fast and reliable internet connection
[*] Not much variety in terms of content; the single player campaign is just a series of battles against CPU opponents.
[*] Depending on your musical tastes, you might not like the soundtrack. This can always be remedied by adjusting the in-game volume settings and playing your own music over the game.
[/list]

[h1] The long version of the review [/h1]
If I was to describe Lethal League in one sentence, it would be Baseball Combat. You play as one of 6 characters, each with a different ability, and you hit the ball back and forth until it hits someone. When you get hit by the ball, you lose a life; when you lose all your lives, you've lost the match. I should note that hitting other characters directly does absolutely nothing, so you have to focus on hitting the ball such that it collides with your opponent. 

Up to 4 players can play at once, and the game modes include a free-for-all deathmatch as well as a team battle mode which supports both 2vs2, 1vs2 and 1vs3 modes. Friendly fire is optional (referred in-game as ball tagging) to allow a more intense experience should you choose to play with it. 

This game is very keyboard friendly if you don't have a controller (as I don't have a very good controller); controlled with the directional arrow keys for movement and the Z, X and Spacebar for other movements, you can re-map all the controls as you see fit in the options menu. My friend can confirm that this game plays great with a controller as well.

Where I think this game shines brightest is its multiplayer, especially when playing with friends. With friends, regardless of how much I was winning or losing, not a moment went by where we weren't having the time of our lives. This game is very easy to learn as the controls are limited to movement, jumping, hitting the ball and bunting the ball (hitting it lightly), and the optional replayable in-game tutorial explains things sufficiently. 

Overall, this game is best played with friends, but can be played just as well solo. Definitely recommended, especially if it's on sale.

I can see why many people would enjoy this game; unfortunately, it lost my interest rather quickly. The concept is well done and original, but both the character options and game itself were too limited for me. 

Lethal league seems like the kind of game that can have a fair amount of depth, but only if you invest in it (which I was not drawn to do). I'll probably play it some more, but only in short bursts.

Based on my own preferences, I can only recommend this game if you're looking for some quick fun with friends (and it's on sale). I'm only writing this review as a warning to those who see the Overwhelmingly Positive score and immediately assume this is worth a buy – watch videos on YouTube before your purchase, as you may have the same issues as me.

If I play this some more and discover some hidden love for it, I'll update this review.

Date: 2/4/16
Review Number: 9
Game: Lethal League
From (Creator Publisher): Team Reptile
Played On: Steambox (Steam Controller)
Steam Price as of Review: $13.99
Total Time played: 45 Minutes
Review:

Admittedly, this is not a game that has come up on the randomizer.  In fact, I think I have decided that once every nine or ten days I think I am going to play a game of my own choosing, in order to balance out the reviews, and to keep me from going crazy.  So I figure the best way to start off my ‘player’s choice’ series would be Lethal League, a multiplayer smash fest from Team Reptile.  Now, I admitted earlier that I really wasn’t that big on fighting games, and in fact often just pounded the controller like I was asking for another beer at a crowded bar hoping the other guy walked into my punches.  I confess now that there was one unmentioned exception to that statement, and that was the classic Nintendo 64 version of smash brothers.  I actually spent a significant amount of time refining my skill in that game, partially because it was a fighting game I was actually fairly decent at, but more because it was oodles of fun, and a great game to play with friends.

Fast forward a decade and change, and we have Lethal League, which is a rehashing of the typical multiplayer chaos on the screen everyone pounding controllers while jumping up and down and ‘accidentally’ kicking each other while playing sort of game, only this time with the added fun of dodgeball rules added in.  See, instead of simply smashing each other directly, players instead knock a little color coded ball back and forth with the goal of hitting someone else, knocking them out until the next serve.  Difficulty is added as the ball’s speed increases every time it is hit, giving players a reward for timing over button mashing.  Each character even has their own special move, from Dice’s occasional arcing of the ball over everyone's’ heads to candyman’s wall-looping trick, each character has a way to frustrate everyone else playing.  And with both online and local multiplayer modes possible, this game will give you enough play value to make it worth any amount of money, and eventual frustration over whoever picks Latch.  Can’t recommend this one enough, folks.  Have fun!

Game’s Fate: Kept.  Also installed on the laptop.  Never know when you want another round
Buy/No Buy: Buy.  Heck, Buy a multipack and send it to all your friends.

Unless you plan to play this with close friends, don't expect reliable online gameplay.

TLDR; Lethal League is an absolutely fantastic game and I cannot wait for the sequel, Lethal League Blaze.

Lethal League is a competitive, multiplayer game that is a spin on sports games and arguably fighting games. You and up to three others have to bounce a ball back and forth until one of you inevitably gets hit by it. It sounds simple but it's so deep and so fun that it's the kind that is easy to pick up and difficult to master. That's where the fighting game comparisons come from. It's basically if a fighting game's only mechanic was teching but instead of teching hits from each other, you tech the ball back and forth. There are different kinds of techniques and special moves to learn to throw off other players and being skillfull and unpredictable with the ball pays off greatly.

The music and art style is beautiful to indulge in. It invokes feelings from games like Jet Set Radio and Smash Bros with its characters embodying a similar culture to that in Jet Set Radio. Every stage has a unique look to it with also unique dynamic screens when the ball gets to a certain speed and every track is great to listen to.

Please support these developers and show them we want more stuff like this. The Lethal League sequel is just around the corner and I am so stoked. They even got JSR's music composer, Hideki Naganuma, to do the music for the new trailer.

Very simple, intuitive mechanics - it's easy to pick up and play, while maintaining a high skill ceiling (see: candychaining)
Some mechanics aren't presented with much depth in the tutorial, so consider spending a while on [b][u]Google to learn about parrying, and Switch's specials[/u][/b]

Online will have you disconnect once or twice before you can connect to an opponent, but once you find a game it can continue as long as you like, I've had one 1v1 go on for a few hours - [strike]relatively short queues, 3 minutes is considered a long queue imo[/strike]

All that being said, I picked up this game recently and have been hooked ever since, and I don't see myself losing interest any time soon

EDIT: One year post-review and [b][u]the online matchmaking is mostly dead[/u][/b], I'd recommend joining a discord community if you want to learn the game. The only people playing right now are the die-hards and tryhards, which makes it difficult to just pick up the game. Grab it if you plan to play with friends or want to actually learn the game.

Quick to learn and hard to master.
Somehow they made hitting a ball back-and-forth tense, exciting, and even hilarious.
Has a jetset-radio sort of look and a soundtrack with the same sort of funky beats.
Has 6 characters that work more differently than you might expect. Each has their own special, a different jump-speed and jump height, slightly different hits, and an extra little thing they can do like cling to walls or double-jump.
I played it for a couple of hours with friends in local-multiplayer and we all enjoyed it.

Fast, challenging and downright insane.
If F-Zero is one of the fastest racing games, then this is one of the fastest beat-em-ups. With a crazy combination of ball game and fighting, be prepared to strain your concentration when you try to find the perfect moment to hit the ball into your opponents face!
If you never had a reason to be scared of a ball, this game will give you more than one reason!

Graphics:
The graphics are cartoony, gritty and occassionally as crazy as the game itself. Despite being handdrawn, the animation is perfectly fluid. The backgrounds are nice to look at yet not distracting in the least and the color coding makes it always easy to know who has control over the ball.

Music:
Each character got their own voice with a set of yells and noises, the music is a funky set of electronic music perfectly fit for the speed of the game.

Gameplay:
Play story mode and fight one up to three AIs, with or without time limit, with or without teams. Play against friends locally or online. Change tagging to allow instant kills, change speed up to 200km/h with one hit. Hit the ball normally, use special skills that confuse your enemies.
The moment you think you know how it works, change the rules and start from the beginning. This game can't be boring. Ever.

Other:
While the story mode is fun, this game HAS to be played with friends. Ideally by friends that are about as good at it as you.
A nice game to play while waiting for something in the backround or if your looking for something to yell at your monitor for.
Simple yet extremely fun with friends

Team Reptile does not copy and paste. There is only 6 characters but each is completely unique.

Lethal League is a 2D fighting game, but unlike traditional fighting games you don’t use fists or kicks or any kind of combat moves. You pick a character and hit an anti-gravity ball against your opponents to beat them, the ball speeds up and bounces harder off the walls with every hit it takes, reaching unbelievably fast speeds - particularly when one charges the hit. All this makes it hard to avoid the ball and also hard to hit the ball. Each player has a certain amount of lives per round and lose them by getting hit with the ball. Once all your lives run out [i]you’re done[/i], and the round ends when there’s only one player left in the game.


[b]Pros:[/b] 
++++ The game is good fast-paced fun, the latency is very comfortable.
+++ The audio and visual aspects are very befitting of each other, especially the effects and art style.
+++ Music is awesome, fits perfectly with the battle atmosphere.
++++ Hitting the ball feels solid, firm – making for immersive projectile battles.
++ Different modes: FFA, TEAM DEATHMATCH
+++ Different characters make for different moves/special moves.
+++++ ”No weak shit.”


[b]Bittersweet:[/b]
-/+ Gameplay is easy to learn but hard to get good at, practice makes perfect and provides hours of fun.
-/+ Speed cap for the ball is ridiculously high, might as well be infinite which makes for difficult but impressive moments.
-/+ Limited player choice, however they are very stylish and have different colour schemes.
-/+ Player base has cool people, but it’s not very big.


[b]Cons:[/b]
-Not really anything negative about the game, if I had to name something it would be the lack of characters and small community.


[b]Final Opinion:[/b]
All in all this game is addictive, exhilarating and a massive amount of fun. It’s as if Super Smash Bros, Pong, and whichever traditional 2D fighting game you can think of had a baby. Easy to pick up, hard to master. Art style, music and gameplay go perfectly well together for an amazing fighting experience.

Lethal League takes a typical dodgeball game and turns it to the max, with CRAZY speeds (once you hit it consistently with one another enough), confined spaces that force you to face the ball head on upon rebound when your friend AKA soon-to-be-enemy sends the not-so-soft-ball straight towards you, Challenge mode that pits you againsts CPUs and varying modes of 1-on-1, 1-on-2, 2-on-2, Against your own shadow, points mode, and even a hidden boss!

Also, despite the max amount of players in a single room being 4, there is still chaos to occur so be lucky it isn't 8 players.

There's good fun/chaos for all!

Amazing mechanics, great twist on the genre, super fun and laughs all around.

I hate Lethal League. I immediately lose respect for anyone who plays it, and especially those who praise it. Here's why:
Name 20 successful people that play it. League of Legends basically runs the show when it comes to games. This includes gamers like Kanye West, Taylor Swift, Lady Gaga, Rihanna, Justin Bieber, Zayn Malik, Adele, Katy Perry, Beyonce et al. LOL has gamers making significant contributions to the entire gaming industry.
Lethal League on the other hand pulls most of the heavy weight packaging from teenage angst with each match. They it lays basic mechanics and a joke of a metagame over it. It generally lags behind LOL by a mile or two in inventiveness. I never see this game at tournaments or mentioned by anyone over the age of 25.
So tell me again, how exactly does Lethal League innovate? It even struggles to release fresh plays with each match, and artwork is about the only original thing with Lethal League.
Yes, Lethal league is stable because it is standing on the shoulders of socially awkward teenagers. Most of the hard work is hashed out before they ever start playing "games". This is fine, and what games are all about, but I prefer to be in with the leaders rather than the followers.
What really irks me and what has really brewed my hatred are Lethal League players. They seem to think Lethal League is responsible for all that is good in the vidya world. I have just proven how false this is. In my experience, Lethal League players (virgins, teenagers, and manchildren) are much less helpful than the alternative.
If you want nice community, play LOL or DOTA. If you like fighting, Divekick. If you prefer, Shaq Fu or Clash of the Monsters. But please, don't feed the idiot magnet that is Lethal League!

On the surface, Lethal League might seem really simple. You just hit a ball until it goes so fast that your opponent gets hit by it and you win. While that’s the jist of it, there’s a lot more to it that makes it fun to play as you make plays (or other people make plays on you). The bunt is an ability that stops the ball dead no matter the speed and pops it up, giving you the opportunity to hit it. With its big hitbox, it’s how you’re gonna turn an enemy’s 2000 mph ball into YOUR 2000 mph ball if you can hit it. When you hit a fast ball, there’s a pause before the ball launches off again and your opponent can time it to hit the ball right as it “unpauses.” At the same time, you can flash a little shield that blocks their hit during the pause if you time it right. And finally, each character has their own special ability that messes with the movement of the ball and makes it less predicable, especially at higher speeds. With all of these little things in place, it makes a weird “Pong fighter” into a chaotic and fun game to play with friends.
There’s one thing to watch out for. This game sometimes has connection issues, so you’ll probably need to pause every few games to remake a lobby because the netcode acted up.

[h1] ***Based on Local Multiplayer Experience *** [/h1]
 
Play With:Controller; Windows 7, Windows 10
 
[h1] Pro: [/h1]
Baseball Fighting: The game has a very interesting system where you fight by hitting a baseball and killing the other players by having that baseball smack into them. The more you hit it the faster it goes, it can even go to a point where the ball sucks up the background and leaves you in a white void. 
 
The Stakes: With each hit the game becomes more tense as the ball speeds up and once it hits that peak speed everyone involved is on the edge of their seat to make sure they don't die. 
 
Music: Each character has a zone and each character has their own theme and all of them are fantastic, the music in this game is great and you should listen to it. 
 
[h1]General Thoughts:[/h1]
This game is amazing. The music, characters and the gameplay all mix to make this wonderfully weird game that is a must for times when you and your friends hang out.

"Lethal League is a competitive projectile fighting game where you have to hit an anti-gravity ball into the face of your opponent to win." That description is spot. Lethal League is a ton of fun though. Once you got used to how the game works the ridiculous amount of things that can happen are endless. The game offers three different game modes; free for all, team, and strikers. Free for all is exactually what you would expect up to for people all trying to knock eachother out by hitting the ball. Team is the same way other than being able to work with your teammate to control the pace of the game. Stirikers is basically soccer where each team is trying to hit the ball into the other teams goal while also trying to protect your own. For free for all I would reccomend three people because with four people the game gets to hectic for me personally. Also the soundtrack in this game is sweet! Overall though I would highly recommend this game to anyone as long as you have friends to play with. I would give this game a solid 8/10 with the only thing holding it back being the replay value since it relies so much on one type of gameplay some people may get bored fairly quickly.

This is my first review, and this game is so awesome I had to create one for it. And don't be fooled by my hours, I'm quite sure there are many more to come. 

TL:DR? Then just buy it. 

If you want to know though, Leath league is...
Super Smash... On PC... with Pixel Art... With a ball... Wait what?! Yea, you can't attack each other. And there's a ball, and you only have 2 attacks, one to hit the ball and one to throw it up. 
So... why is this even good? 
The Ball speeds up when you hit it, and even more if you throw it up then hit it. And the most important thing is... if you get hit by the ball and your opponent was the one to hit it last, you're out. No hp bar, just out. 
Soon you realize you get into some intense Sudden death action, when the ball is flying around on the screen at 50 speed and you're a one shot out. But if you hit the ball and it goes fast enough that the enemy dosen't have enough time to stop it,  they're out. You start to go crazy waiting for the inevitable out of yourself or the other player, nobody ever has a sure chance of winning. You even start to scream and squel every time you die or kill the enemy.

All in all, epic game. Buy it if you like crazy intense action. If not, buy it anyway.

To start off. This game is defenitly different than your average 2D fighter. With a very simular aspect of a Super Smash Bros. game, It's A four-player game with a objective that's not beating up another player until their health gauge is gone. Instead your hitting a ball at intense velocities slowly creeping up in momentum until one of the players hits it back faster or is knocked out by the ball. This is where it gets insane. Each character, despite its low roster, has special abilities to either make the ball move faster or cause insane mix-ups on the other players. They all have simular properties to SSB characters: like fast falling, Dash Dancing, and floaties. The big thing that you need to learn in this game is not really the technical prowess, but learning the frames of the game, predicting where the balls is going to go, and timing every hit correctly. 

Aside from all this jibber jabber, this game offers minimal stuff to do aside from leveling up, unlocking skins, and comepleting a offline challange mode simular to a arcade mode of somesort. The online takes a while to  find any kind of matches including 1 on 1 or a free for all battle but I have yet to run into a  match where it's just miseriably laggy. 

If you want a hype, over the top, different 2d fighter game; play this, enjoy it with your friends or go online and smash some scrubs. I'd definintly recommend this game.

Have you ever thought to yourself what it would be like if you put yourself in a box with three other players and you all had sticks and just started beating the crap out of a ball that did not have a gravitational pull and try to get your opponents out with said speedball? This is Lethal League. It's a very fun game overall, here's some of the advantages and disadvantages:

Advantages:
Fast-paced, intensive action
Overall good color scheme, in addition to decent soft techno music playing each level
Very easy to connect to online, nothing to it!
A great game to play with friends as skill level is not necessarily always the factor in each game, more or less luck

Disadvantages:
Over time the game shows less and less frame rate, like a battery depleting over time
Some move mechanics are a little iffy, and could use some touch up to make smoother
neutral balls (both players hit the ball at the same exact time) hinder too long of a stun, rendering either/or player useless.

Overall: 8 out of 10

A game that seems simple at first glance, but has a surprisingly high skill ceiling. This unique "fighting" game still has me on the edge of my seat, with intense high-speed battles.

Lethal League plays a bit differently than other fighting games, since you have little effect on your opponent directly. Instead, to knock them out, you must hit a levitating ball and land a direct hit, while your opponent tries to do the same to you. Mind-games come into play as you can hit the ball under an angle up and down, which causes it to bounce rapidly around the stage!

Other features: Sweet music and high moddability (Sprites, music, UI).

While the GGPO connection actually works great (A high ping player will bring down any game, really) once the match has started, there are some issues when starting the match, occasionally locking up the game. The devs seem to want to try to fix this issue currently, so hopefully this (pretty big) flaw will be sorted out soon.

---
[h1]Review[/h1]

As I have said, Lethal League is a very fun multiplayer game. It is easy to learn but hard to master, and has a pretty high skill cap.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Memorable catchy house music.
[*] A unique concept of pong/baseball/fighting all combined into one game that is really blood-pumping and may cause some screaming if you're playing a LAN.
[*] Solid mechanics
[*] The controls are tight
[*] 6 different characters you can choose from with different abilities (and hit angles).
[*] You can play in quick short bursts, maybe when you're queuing for a Dota 2 game, CSGO, anything really.
[*] The art is unique.
[*] The animations are very smooth.
[*] The voice acting isn't cringe-worthy and is very well done.
[*] Playing with lag is somewhat manageable, unlike in some FPS and other games where lag is very important to not have.
[*] Hardly any bugs.
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Current playerbase isn't too big so actually finding a game is sometimes impossible. You can check on [url=https://steamdb.info/app/261180/]SteamDB[/url] to see how many players are playing at the moment so you can actually find an opponent.
[*] Price is a bit too expensive for some people.
[*] Rare crashes.
[/list]

That's all I could think of for cons, really.

[h1]Wishlist[/h1]
The things I wish was in the game
[list]
[*] More characters
[*] A cheaper price to increase the playerbase
[/list]

[h1]FINAL VERDICT:[/h1]
[i][b]85/100[/b][/i]

Casual competitive hyperspeed mayhem. Up to four players smash a floating baseball around an enclosed arena with the goal of striking the opposing players with the ball. The players all begin with eight lives. The winner is the last one standing. Six different characters are available to choose from, each one with unique angles for striking the ball, individual special attacks, and particular jump heights. Skill, technique, and mindgames are tested in each match, and only one may win in a battle to the death.

The simplicity of the controls provide a low barrier to entry to allow players of all skill levels to compete, at which point strategy and technique come into play much earlier than other competitive games. Game players initially timid to try Lethal League due to a perceived difficulty curve soon find themselves cheering uproariously at their victories and groaning sorely at their losses, yet smiling cheerfully all the while. This game really brings out a competitive spirit in the people I’ve played with, most of whom don't play games regularly, while keeping things fun.

Like a good sequel should, [strike] Call of Duty: Ghosts [/strike] Lethal League doesn’t ignore the formula of fast, fluid gameplay that has made the series famous, but introduces a unique new premise, unprecedented player personalization, and sweeping changes that breathe new life into the multiplayer experience. It’s over-the-top and at times unnecessarily complex, but serves both current and next-generation consoles with ambitious new ideas and tremendous replay value.

Despite sharing a name with one of [strike] Modern Warfare’s [/strike] Lethal League best-known characters, Ghosts takes place in an entirely new Call of Duty universe set in the not-too-distant future. In a genre overwrought with antiquated Russian conflicts and ambiguous Middle Eastern terrorist threats, Ghosts takes on a refreshingly unique premise in which the threat comes not from the east, but the south: a federation of oil-rich South American nations rises to take over the hemisphere, pushing north and coming to blows with the U.S.

The prelude establishes a harrowing vision of a United States homeland that's broken but not beaten – not quite Red Dawn, but not Fallout 3, either. It’s a space not often explored by modern shooters, and its mood is heightened by missions set in a besieged Santa Monica and the wasted remains of San Diego, to the tune of an excellent, somber score from David Buckley (The Town, Metal Gear Solid 4). But ultimately, time on the poignant homefront is short lived as the story goes behind enemy lines in Caracas, the Andes mountains, and other exotic locales.

Those might lack to familiarity, but the variety of environments keeps the campaign fresh, not only in terms of visuals, but in gameplay as well. Instead of just fighting waves of enemies through a linear stage at ground level, you’ll find yourself rappelling down skyscrapers, flying helicopters, having firefights in space, commanding tanks, scuba diving through shipwrecks, playing as a dog, and evading shark attacks. Each requires new strategy, acute situational awareness, and – in the case of the space and water missions – special consideration for verticality and physics.

Of course, it wouldn’t be a Call of Duty game without elaborate setpieces, fierce shootouts, and tense stealth missions, and Ghosts delivers some of the most memorable experiences in the series. I felt genuine dread as the ground and buildings collapsed around me during orbital weapons strikes, the zero-gravity spectacle of the Federation’s space station ambush is awe-inspiring, and bursting through a highrise window as the entire building crumbles during the Federation Day mission is exhilarating.

But like previous CoDs, the story of Ghosts struggles to remain in focus amidst the fray of explosive cinematic moments and relentless firefights. Narrated loading sequences with stylized story animations push the campaign forward, but only last for one or two minutes before launching back into the action. It’s there, on the front lines, that much of the plot progression is presented and oftentimes lost.

It's by no means an achievement in dramatic storytelling — it's more about dumb fun — and it lacks the player-choice element introduced with Call of Duty: Black Ops II, but when given time to breathe Ghosts actually offers some interesting human drama. The story centers around two brothers, Logan and Hesh, their father Elias, and yes, their dog Reilly as they fight the Federation as part of the battered remnants of the U.S. military, and later as the elite Ghosts squad. The family ties, specifically the relationship between Logan and Hesh, made me care about the protagonists in a series that's habitually made its characters a dispensable commodity. The voice acting is decent overall, though there are periodic moments of cringe-worthy dialog, like one superfluous moment when Elias reveals he’s a member of the Ghosts. And then there’s Riley. Though the subject of many a meme at this point, Riley not only acts as a useful tool for recon and silently dispatching enemies, but is integral to several dramatic sequences, saving your character on more than one occasion.

The story stumbles in the second act when it strays away from the more evocative character focus in favor of a long stretch of back-to-back missions driven almost exclusively by guns-blazing combat. While not poorly done, this visually arresting, action-packed, but ultimately hollow middle stands in stark contrast to the effective first and final acts. On the bright side, that padded out my play time to roughly 10 hours, making this campaign one of the longest CoD single-player experiences.

The Verdict
[strike] Call of Duty: Ghosts [/strike] Lethal League isn't a reinvention of the franchise, but proves there's still room for innovation within its existing formula. Though at the risk of overcomplicating things at times, its robust multiplayer gameplay, surprisingly fun co-op modes, and lengthy, challenging, and varied campaign makes [strike] Ghosts [/strike] Lethal League one of the best Call of Duty games to date.

Lethal League. Jolly ol' Lethal League.
What can I say about this game, considering I just got it yesterday? A lot. I guess.

THE STORY:
There is no story. :/

THE GAMEPLAY:
Imagine Super Smash Bros. with no platforms floating in the sky. Then, add dodgeball into the mix. Yeah. Dodgeball. Who doesn't like that maniacal, murderous hellfest of a game? It's better than it sounds though, which means there won't be any dodgeballs flying at your literal face. Realism.
The controls are pretty simple. You use the left and right arrow keys to move... fairly simple. Z to attack... sure. X to stop the ball from zip-zapping all over the place... cool. Spacebar to jump... aweso--
Wait a sec... the Spacebar to jump? That's a bit unexpected for a Steam game, don't you think?
When you hit the ball, you can use the up and down keys to set the angle you're going to hit the ball with.
You have 8 lives by default (you can change it in settings) and it's your job to knock out your opponents one by one. When the ball is your colour, it can't hurt you at all. Or can it? I have no idea.
In terms of colours, P1 has red, P2 has blue, P3 has yellow and P4 has green. Cool.
Like Smash Bros, there are different skins (or "flavours") for each character. None of the skins, heck, none of the characters play any different. So really, you can just choose any character without any problems.
Unless...
The special attacks!
Each character has their own special attack. Candyman has Candyball (in which the ball can teleport through walls and look like an awesome face while it's at it), Latch has...
Um...
...
Serves me right for only playing as Candyman.
What can I say? I love him and his jawbreakers. No matter how weird they taste. (innuendo not intended)
You can hit the ball 4 times until you can use your special attack. Just press Z two times. It doesn't always work though.

THE GAMEMODES:
Online, versus, challenge and training. That's it.
But, there are sub-gamemodes in the versus mode. There's free-for-all (self-explanatory), team (again, self explanatory) and strikers (each team has to hit the ball in the goals they're trying to attack. In other words... soccer.

THE VISUALS:
The visuals are kinda like the 2003 Ninja Turtles cartoon. Cartoonish, but pretty edgy as well. The graphics look a bit pixel-y, but they do the job well.

THE MUSIC:
Not the best soundtrack. The tracks are pretty cool, but I'd be screwed if I remember what they sound like.
They're better than my music though. I'll tell you that.

PROGRESSION:
Each time you play the game, you earn EXP. You all know what that is. Progressing to more levels gives you new "flavours" to try out. I especially like the black Candyman. He tastes like licorice.

FINAL VERDICT:
The game is pretty fun and memorable, and it's one of the most innovative Steam games I've seen (and this game was made in the 2010's, when Call of Duty was still around). Sadly, there is no local multiplayer, but I'll forgive it, considering that it's not frickin' Fireboy and Watergirl.
My final word on this game is that this game is... GREAT.

Lethal League is a game in which 2-4 players hit a baseball back and forth until one gets hit... Okay, it doesn't sound that cool on paper but beleive me this concept works without a doubt!
There are six characters to chose from: Candyman, Sonata, Raptor, Switch, Dice and Latch, they all have plenty of skins ('Flavours' as the game calls them) to chose from. All of the characters play the same except from their Special Move (Which, if you're familiar with Super Smash Brothers, is sort of like every characters 'Final Smash') I would have prefered If the Characters had different moves than eachother as this would make each of them feel a lot more special rather than a simple palette swap.
The game also features a leveling system in which each time you level up, you gain a new flavour for each character. There is also a Challenge mode in which you fight each character one after and they get progessivly get stronger as you fight more.
The soundtrack in the game is amazing, consisting of high-pace electronic music which fits the pace of each match perfectly. 
The controls, whilst confusing at first, feel very fluid and give a great experience. The game plays a lot like Super Smash Brothers with a primary move, secondary move and a big finishing 'Special move'

[U]PROS:[/U]
[list]
    [*]Great Soundtrack
    [*]High replay value thanks to Online and Challenge mode
    [*]Fluid controls
[/list]

[U]CONS:[/U]
[list]
    [*]Characters feel 'Copy and Pasted'
[/list]

Lethal League is a what you get when you cross a fighting game with dodgeball in all the best ways.  Players jockey to control a small ball, hitting it around the screen in an attempt to knock out eachother.  Every hit on the ball speeds it up, and it quickly moves from an easy to predict slow moving projectile to a streak that bounces around the screen, ricocheting off ceiling, walls, and floor to take out players.  

This simple set up leads to an exciting and incredibly fun game.  Unlike most fighting games, there are no long lists of special moves to learn and memorize (each character has slightly differnt angles they will hit the ball at, and a special move that can be powered up during play and used, but no difficult button combos are required for any moves).  This makes the game very intuitive and easy for players to jump in and start playing, even if you are not into fighters.  However, the interplay between player and their specials does lead to a suprising amount of depth in the combat, and learning the timing to intercept balls as they come off of other players at higher speeds will take practice.  

If I had any criticisms for the game, it would be that the simplicity of it can be a double edged sword.  Games can start feeling repetative during long play sessions.  Game options can extend this a bit, but in the end most feel gimicky and I find myself losing interest after 30-60 minutes.  However, that being said, I still find myself coming back to this game to get in a few quick rounds against friends when we don't have time for a long playsession, or to finish out a night of gaming.  And that is where the game shines imho, quick bursts of action and excitement when I don't have the time to spend hours playing.

This games perfectly fills a niche in my gaming library.  It is well worth the price (and worth getting a few extra copies for your friends as well).  An unreserved thumbs up from me.

Lethal League is best described as "Battle Squash". Similar to the indoor sport, the object is to hit a ball as fast as you can so it will rebound towards your opponent, the only difference being that you are TRYING to hit them. It's the first fighting game I know of where player contact is actually very discouraged. The ball will gain speed with each hit, and with each character boasting their own unique 'special' moves, the game can get extremely tense very quickly. 

If you like fighting games, this translates very easily, and becomes basically hardcore tennis, where the object is to get the other player 'out' by hitting them with the ball. As you can imagine, with more speed, this becomes trickier, as the frame window where you can hit the ball is VERY small and requires a keen sense of timing. Very fun, very easy to get used to, and allowing up to four players at a time, which is very rare in the world of fighting games.

The game is simple: think of it like... racketball, with an anime escalation twist. Battle Pong. --PCMasterRace Solution--------------
The offending file is "candy_gethit_b.wav"

It's located at ...\lethalleague\resources\audio\voiceover\candy\

Open with Audacity (free software, and awesome), delete the swearing, and export/overwrite back to .wav

Now it's just a grunt.

Really, this game has the potential to be very fun. In the most basic game, you hit a ball back and forth; if it hits you, you're out for the round. And it gains speed at every swing. So pretty simple, really. And hilarious. You can play local multiplayer or online multiplayer, and there's also a single player mode ("challenge mode") which is a set amount of matches against set characters and combinations. The game modes are free-for-all (just hitting the ball until only one player remains), team play (works best for four players, obviously) and strikers (hit the other team's goal instead of its players).

The problem with this game is that if you're playing alone, there really isn't much to do besides challenge mode - which, honestly, I didn't find it as fun as multiplayer. You can try to search for matches online, but most of the time it's just unfruitful, and the online mode has quite a few connectivity issues, especially if the match has more than two players. The game also gets repetitive quite fast, and while leveling up does unlock new things, they're mostly skins for the characters (there are 6 different in the game) which are purely cosmetic and honestly not that rewarding.

Still, if you have a couple friends willing to engage in some pong-esque shenanigans, maybe over a skype call or even some pizza at your house, I can recommend getting a multi-pack of this game and bash away.

I haven't played it too much just yet, but it's already a ludicrous amount of fun. Imagine the weird offspring of Smash Brothers, dodgeball and Pong. Cover it in an art style similar to Jet Set Radio. Add quirky characters and you're all set. Lethal League is one of those games that's difficult to describe. Though there have probably been similar games before it, this one does enough new things that make it unique.  You start out in an arena hitting a ball around. If you hit the ball, it turns your color. When you hit an opponent with the ball, they die. Last one standing wins. Last won standing after ten lives is declared the winner of the match.  To win, the game requires you to have cat like quickness. Each hit that the ball takes from a player it speeds up. The more players hit it, the faster it will go. Matches are usually five minutes at the most, so this game is great to kill a few spare minutes if you have a busy schedule. I would highly recommend this game to those who want to try a unique take on some well-known game mechanics. The game is fast, competitive and hell of a lot of fun.

This game is an odd mashup of things like Tekken, Super Smash Bros, Pong, and a bit of Dragonball Z mixed in for good measure.  If you get a couple of friends and all play together, this game is one of the best times you'll collectively have.  I haven't played in the open multiplayer so I can't vouch for the online community, but playing against friends is simply fantastic.  The online multiplayer will occasionally desyncronize when starting a match, but it only takes about 10 seconds to exit the game, restart it, host a new lobby, invite your friends into it, and restart.  The desync error also is not particularly common, certainly less than 10% of matches will have this issue.  Not a serious detraction from the overall game.

There are, however, two things missing: a replay system and a spectator mode.  There are many situations where it would be nice to have a replay so you can answer questions like "How did that shot hit me?" or "That was an awesome move, can I see that again?"  I hope the devs will eventually include some form of replay management.  The inclusion of a spectator mode would make this game viable for some tournaments and casting.  I doubt it'll rival things like LoL or DOTA for popularity, but at some events it would be great to have a Lethal League tournament going on as a side-attraction or something.

At first this game seems pretty simple, dodge the ball and hit it to the oponent, and that is pretty much it really...

Newcomers to the game will get hit by some slow moving balls, trying to see the ball coming towards them. The fact is, that the ball will reach incredible speeds, making it litterally impossible to see coming. However it is not impossible to predict. The fighting term "yomi" is a perfect word to describe this game, "yomi" meaning predicting your opponent's actions.

Although this game doesn't make it totaly impossible, there is a bar at the bottom of the screen that will fill up during a hit, sometimes quick, sometimes slow. Once it fills the ball will fly out. many players abuse this to hit the ball in the same place, I assume programmers saw this so they created a shield you can activate for a brief period at the cost of your meter, from 1/4 to full. If the other player hit's this, he will be stunned and sent towards the projectile, most of the time...

This game has tons of replayability, I really recomend it.

One of the absolute best ideas for a competitive multiplayer game ever dreamt up, the prototype was already great, but now the release game blows that out of the water sky high.

Lethal League combines fast gameplay, stylized music, original retro 2D art (reminds me of the Jet Set Radio series in a lot of ways), and competitive online multiplayer to make one hell of a fun and original fighting game.

For people looking for a fresh new concept and fast paced multiplayer (and singleplayer) action, I can not recommend this game enough.

The best way to describe Lethal League is as a simplification of the fighter genre mixed with a projectile game.

Divekick did that in that fact that instead of having complicated moves, it became more about timing and mind games.

Lethal League does that in your positioning, your timing (although its pretty easy to get good at that), and your ability to change things up enough to freak out the opponent. If you don't mess with their head, and you're both good at the timing and positioning, the game can go on for a long time.

It's a lot about making less mistakes than the other person. In fact, that's pretty much how you win.

But enough about that, why should you play this game?

PROS:
- Easy to just play, easy to get good at, but relatively hard to get REALLY good at
- Can keep you busy with just the singleplayer, but has a decent online matchmaking system, as well as local and online 4 player, similar to smash bros
- Good at not frustrating the player, the most fun way to play if the best way to win
- Gameplay that manages to be fast but also slow??? It works, trust me
- Awesome music
- Funky art
- No weak shit

CONS:
- Small character roster (Also a pro because it's easier to learn everything)
- Much lower skill cap than other fighters (doesn't mean it can't be competetive)
- Really grindy level up system (at least you get rewards for every level in the form of colour palletes and different balls which change up gameplay)

In short, if you like unique fighters, or Jet Set Radio, or both (like me), this game should be appealing to you.
Also a good party game. Not that I'd know.

It's pretty much fighting game perfection. It's a simple concept but with a surprisingly huge amount of depth and nuance to it, from the way the characters have their own individual quirks to the slight differences in stages changing the gameplay.

If you're a big fighting game fan either competitively or casually, you'd be doing yourself a disservice in not picking this game up.

TLDR; Amazingly fun and replayable competitive online game plagued by HORRIBLE connections.

Unnaceptable that a game of this low of graphical fidelity would have such terrible connection / lag issues.

How do I describe this game?.......
Lethal leauge is how many peopke describe it, a mix between PONG and Super Smash Bros. The main idea is you and up to 3 other players hit a small ball that seems to lack gravity or air resistance inbetween each other. When you hit the ball it get's 'tagged' with your color, and if someone gets hit with the ball when it's not tagged their color they're out.

There's a lot more to it than that, like stage sizes and hit angles, but if you want a fun little game you ca jump into whenever and mess around with friends, or compete in actual tournaments, this game is for you.

It's also a very chaotic game, however. At times you and someone else will end up getting one of you out, then thinking 'What the hell just happened?' And usually it can be a bit jarrring, especially at higher ball speeds when the screen starts shaking and you have to factor in hit lag.

Overall, I give this game a 10/10. Really. I have no complaints.

Well now that I'm almost at 30 hours of game time I might as well say something about it. I purchased this game right after seeing Total Biscuit and friends play this in his first impressions video for this game. It looked like exactly my kind of game, and it is.

The controls are so tight and the animations feel so right. Every stupid little combos and moves you concoct feel so satisfying and absolutely amazing. The gameplay is very simple but to master it would take a very long time. I will be playing this game for years to come for sure and you should too!

Athletes, Olympians and war heroes. You've been gathered here in this call because you are the greatest in your fields. We've got a nifty ball here that can break the speed of light but we need your help to get it that fast.

Now you might be thinking: "Jokr, how can we get something that fast when neurons in the body can't come close to the speed of sound?" That's where the Aperture Sceince Acceleration Rod come in. You put that peice of science into your favorite weapon of choice and when that ball is burning ozone towards your head, you just swing it and smash it right back even faster then before.

Greg here tells me that if some how that ball makes contact with you without being contained by the Acceleration Rod, all the electrons in your body will change into white light waves and you'll shoot right through the Earth's core. Now don't you worry Old Jokr Goblin here has you covered. We'll bend the path of your electrons so you'll just pass through the Aperture Science Prism Collector and you'll just drop back down from the ceiling like nothing even happened to you. 

The Prism Collector can only do this five times per person before too much your mass is absorbed by Earth's mass, but to bend time and space to your will is certainly the cost. You got to crack a few eggheads to make a make an fast then light omlette. Also we'll be recording this for something we call.. "Lethal Leauge." So... Who's ready to do some science?"

WIIIIPEOUT! Lethal League is a somewhat simplistic fighting game of the same nature as DiveKick, where you have to own the ball to own the court. Don't let this fool you, however: Each of the 6 characters has their own unique jumping style, angle of attack, and powerful special move to unleash at just the right moment. For instance, Latch can grab the ball in his mouth and fire it back out at another angle; Raptor slams it twice in quick succession; Candyman (who just wants to watch the world burn) lets loose a menacing jawbreaker that goes through walls, the ceiling, and even the floor to wrap around the other side of the pitch. Rounds are fast and frenetic, with the ball bouncing faster and faster with every hit, which means there's very little time to stay mad at whatever killed you last. GGPO support means you can play with people from across the globe without worrying about severe lag.

What is this game worth? Probably about $10.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Excellent concept - bringing such a fresh breath of life to stale fighting games
+Brilliantly simple controls - no tedious combos to memorize
+Characters each have their own specialties - it seems subtle, though
+Music is pretty good

[b]Cons:[/b]
-While this game is crazy fun, there is wasted potential at this point IMO, I really think there is TONS of room for expansion, such as:
-Needs more playable characters
-Needs better artwork, IMO
-Needs more playable levels
-Needs more gameplay modes (only 3 right now)

Overall, the fun factor is pretty much through the roof with this title. If you have couch coop opportunities, this is a no brainer.

When it comes to fighting games, I'm not usually a huge fan. Lethal League brings a new and engaging twist to the idea: Instead of hitting each other with your fists, you hit a ball at them, and they can hit it back. It turns into a game of timing and skill, rather than just button mashing. A relatively easy concept to learn, but beyond that, there are plenty of ways you can go about out-balling your opponent. Very cool, and very fun.

+ Great music and art style, reminds me of Jet Set Radio

Cons: 
Very basic features
Need four other friends to play with

Lethal League is a group party game that play's like a bizarre mix between Pong, Dodge Ball, and Smash Bros. There are 6 characters to choose from, each with slightly different mechanics and playstyle. Whenever you hit the ball, it gains speed and turns your color, becoming able to kill your opponents if they can't deflect it and becoming unable to kill you. You and 1-3 other players keep building speed trying to eliminate eachother as the chaos element grows exponentially. Rounds are short as you try to get as many points as you can. As you play, you unlock a couple additional play modes and character pallet swaps.

Really good game. My only real complaints are that the story mode is balls hard in the later levels, and that online play with randos online can become fairly laggy. Really, the main draw of this game is playing with friends on a game night, either locally or by hosting a private server. The game will give you probably 5-15 hours of solid play with friends, although I'd prefer the more fleshed out sequel. This game on sale is a nice low-investment starting point though, if you want to buy a 4-pack for you and your friends/game group before deciding on the superior, more pricey sequel.

Also the style of the game is really awesome, graphically, story-wise, characters, and music. It reminds me a little bit of those late 90's/early 00's Sega games (Crazy Taxi, Power Stone, and especially Jet Set Radio). I REALLY wish more games went for this kind of style, as it's simultaneously cool, cheesy, endearing, and nostalgic.

Fun and exciting to play, and to watch. While still being legitimately competetive. Lethal League is relatively bare, being a game about hitting a ball into dudes, with all the different buttons being different ways of hitting said ball, yet it is highly focused and concise.

If you were one of those people who thought Divekick's bare-bones gameplay was quite a groundbreaking thing, but were bummed to discover the novelty wore off very quickly or otherwise never understood it in the first place, then maybe Lethal League will leave a better taste in your mouth. Even if you don't plan on playing it until you're one of the best ball-bunters online, you will be giddy with excitement everytime the ball accelerates to mach speeds and every strike is empowered with tense build-up. It is the most anime thing ever and it is great. (Disclaimer: This user does not personally invest in this application of the term "anime". Interpret loosely.)

Here's to hoping Lethal League gets continued support, as well as sustained recognition.

This game is amazing, full stop. The audio, the graphics,  the gameplay, list goes on and on and on. However, despite the sheer awesomeness of this game there are a few problems which i will address : 

-playerbase/multiplayer wait time
The amount of time untill i find one player is beyond insane. Prior to buying lethal league i looked at the amount of players present and to my suprise i saw 600-700 people, i thought well, since this is primarily aimed towards multiplayer, the amount of players should fine. A few minutes later i reassured myself and bought it. After the totorial of lethal league i did not waste any time, i decided to play my first lethal league multiplayer match.........It took ages, but then a guy named Squaresx5 saved me from my misery, i pounced in joy breaking my chair in the process. I was so happy, even though i was a noob and knowing that i will slaughtered. 

-Replay value
I know the time i accumulated is trivial which results in my review being little to no significance, but from first sight, the HUD, the menu and so on i seem to be getting the same message all around the place. CONTENT? REPLAYIBILTY?  but dont get me wrong, it is immensely fun and a good time waster here and then, after awhile though... it kinda loses the appeal, hence people leave. This problem will ultimately affect the player base and the overall longevity of the game.

Stuff to consider adding in the future:
+stats
+stuff to buy and enhance. new abilities?, potions?, weapons?.
+faster multiplayer connection
+new maps and new characters
+new modes
+and events
+leaderboard?

It is one of the most addicting games I have played in ages. Best described as Battle Pong on Steroids with a hint of baseball, the aim  of the game is to bat the ball back and forth between you and your opponent until one of you slips and gets hit.

So here's the thing. Lethal League technically doesn't have a lot of content. I'm about 8 hours in and I've already maxed level and beaten the arcade mode once. But we have an old saying in the male community. "It's not the size, it's how you use it". This game is horrendously fun in multiplayer. The controls are tight and the netcode is top notch quality. The game relies on two things to make multiplayer fun: Satisfaction value and reaction time. Luckily, it nails both of them. First of all, I'll actually explain the game. It works in a small square room (One of five maps) and a ball spawns in the middle. Every time a player hits the ball, it becomes his color and it cannot hurt him, only his enemies. While hitting the ball he can also do two things: Aiming the ball up or down and activating his special ability. The special abilities add some depth due to learning how each should be used to the best effect. For example, one characters special allows the ball to travel through walls for a little while. At first I only tried to fake people out with it on the ground, and catch them unawares. But over time I learned that if I applied an aim to it I could cause it to go flying through the ground and the cieling at an angle, which is incredibly hard to perdict and dodge accordingly. Alright, on to the aforementioned satisfaction value. As the ball gets to higher and higher velocites, each smacking of the ball results in the player smacking the ball for not only about 5-6 seconds straight, but also the screen freaking out to high hell. So basically, every time you hit the ball, it feels like you just punched through the earth. Additionally, the music is some of the best I've ever heard in a video game. The tracks are nice and varied, with each track seemingly blending in with the endless sounds of the ball getting smacked into the fifth dimension. The one aspect which can devide people is the art style. It's a simplistic art style, no doubt, but some will find it attractive and some will find it boring. It's really just a matter of opinion. All in all, it's a blast with friends and the soundtrack is amazing, but if you just want to find a good solo experience, I don't know why you're looking at an arena fighting game.

This game is one of the best multiplayer games I've played in a long time! Everytime I play, it feels like play Super Smash Bros back in the day. Very fun mechanics with a ton of skill and subtle fighting game stylizations thrown in! Very good game!

I learned of this game from watching TotalBiscuit's "WTF is..." about it and to me it seemed like a hilarious game concept.

Now after about 3 hours spent in in, getting myself to lv10 I feel I can write a review of my own.

This game is Awesome xD
It might seem simple, and it is, but sometimes simple fun is better than overly complicated things. In this game you fight your opponents by hitting a ball at them and that's it, on the surface. It's basically an easy to learn and hard to master game.
Each character of the 5 you (at least currently) have to choose from has their own abilities, for one they all have different jumps of varying height and I think their movement speed varies too but it might be the visuals tricking me. On top of that they all have different special attacks, one makes the ball warp through the arena wall and come out on the other side, one double swings at the ball to increase the speed by ridiculous amounts and so on. Making use of those skills correctly is what will set you apart from the rest in the end.

The game has a singleplayer component but I don't see why you'd wanna play against AI opponents in a game like this.

The netcode for the multiplayer seems quite good, but it you want a lag free game I still recommend just going 1 vs 1. From what I gathered it's not perfected for more players yet but it's still posible to play a 4 player free for all with no issues, but know that there might be disconnects or desyncs happening in those.

The visuals aren't amazing but for this kind of game they work quite well. Not all games has to be super flashy 3D and stuff, if the game works better with a simple 2D look then that's the better choise in my opinion.

The music for the game is great. I haven't heard a track in there that I wish wasn't playing, overall really good sound effects too.

I personally recommend playing on a controller but I'm sure it works fine on keyboard too, all keys are cusomizable for your comfort.

Scores for those who need them:

Graphics - 7 - It fits the style of the game but I'd be lying if I gave it a higher score.
Sound and Music - 8.5 - Overall great, but not quite enough to get me to want the soundtrack.
Gameplay - 9.5 - For such a simple game it's amazingly fun, probably even more so if you have three friends to play with.

Overall score - 8.4 - I recommend you get it, if you're hesistant wait for a sale :D

The idea of a competetive sports game isn't that uncommon. In the early days there was Windjammers. A discthrowing 1v1 pong-like game in a form of a fightinggame with different specialmoves and characters.
This game on the other hand takes those Ideas and give them a new look and feel and resembles one of the most unique games of this decade.


#### What are we doing exactly? #####
The goal of the game is getting a ball to hit your opponents. You can hit the ball in many directions and the ball is bouncing of the walls. There are different attacks and specials you can do to speed up the ball or causing it to change directions.

####### Gameplay ######
Smooth as butter. Easy to learn, hard to master. You can get relatively far with just playing with feel and a little bit random button presses. But if you learn how to combo, parry and reducing your hitlag, you can get constant wins.

####### Graphics #######
The graphics are completely 2D. It looks like it was done by MS Paint, but it has its own funky style. The graphics are snappy and look good. Especially the effects when you hit the ball as it reaches the speeds of  max 1000000pixel/s (I think thats the speedindex)

####### Balance ########
The game seems to be well balanced. Every character is different and has a specialattack and peculiarities like walljump, doublejump, wallclinging and driving across the ceiling with a skateboard. Also the angles, in which the ball flies after a hit, are different aswell. Because it is more about how you handle the ball, i don't think there will be overpowered characters.

####### Network ########
The netcode is powered by ggpo. You can feel how good the netcode is.. even with 4 players it's smooth as hell. There are some hickups, witch result in disconnects, but considering the age of the game, I wouldn't be surprised if the game got some updates to fix this. After all it's just a little annoyance, which is forgotten after you desperately try to reconnect to the massive fun. (which is fast anyway)

###### Conclusion ######
The game is a must-have. The fun we had in just 6 hours was tremendous. The game is best played with 4 players, in a 2v2 teammatch.

Lethal League is a truly hillarious, over the top take on pong and fighting games.

The general concept is to defeat your opponentt and reduce their stocks (think smash bros) by smashing them with the ball. The ball will deal damage to your opponents after you hit it, but can be hit by them, which can then cause it to deal damage to you. As in pong, you keep rallying the ball back and forth, with it getting faster and faster until one of you is hit, at which point you lose a life and the ball resets. 

What sounds like a very simple concept rapidly becomes a hillarious series of "Oh shit!" moments in which the ball is going so incredibly fast that you'd think it impossible to hit, but then someone does, and it gets even faster.

Throw in a bunch of colourful and creative characters and stages, along with an incredible sound track, and some very fancy and flashy visual and sound effects that wouldn't feel out of place in an Anime or Manga, and you get an enjoyable and hillarious experience.

Would reccomend playing with friends (up to 4 player) for added hillarity and fun.

Lethal League is comparable to a game of tennis or pong. Except totally insane and chaotic. And you aim to kill your opponent with the ball instead of passing them. While there's order in the chaos, nothing is more fun to get the ball speed up to insane heights and hope you survive. 

The game rules and controls are simple and to the point; hit the ball, bunt the ball and jump to avoid the ball, while trying to hit other characters with it. Each of the 5 characters has their own specific special abilities.

There might be a learning curve when it comes to timing your shots and being able to track the ball the faster it goes, but with practice comes alot of fun, and when you master it, it gets EVEN BETTER. It's recommended to play with friends, locally or online, but randoms can be fun too if you find the right guy.

GGPO, this game's online component, is a little more tighter than done with Street FIghter 3: Online edition, altho sometimes you notice people dying yet not, but the game is so fast you don't care anyway and adjust accordingly.

If there's one slight I would give this game: Not too often, It can and will crash at a certain point, persumably one of the characters specials will hit the ball and might crash one of the players out of the game. It's a sad thing too, because other times it won't happen and gameplay flows fine. I'm expecting this to be fixed in an upcoming patch of some sort.

All in all, an excellent fun and simple game that gets deeper the more you get into it, and a great way for a bunch of buds to spend some time smacking each other in the face with high velocity balls.

I guess I'll start this review like everyone else started their own review:

No weak shit.

Lethal League is a projectile fighting game that plays like nothing else I know of. To make immediate comparisons, it's like Smash Bros meets Pong meets Divekick, with a lot of emphasis on the Divekick part. The goal of the game is incredibly simple: hit the ball to gain control of it, try to smack it into everybody else. If someone else hits the ball, don't get hit and try to return the ball.

This game is deceptively simple, and I say this because even though the mechanics are limited, the ways in which you use those mechanics are actually fairly deep. You have two main actions you can take, you can hit the ball or you can bunt the ball. When you hit the ball, you can either send it flying straight, or angle it up or down. Bunting the ball will slow it down to its lowest possible speed and pop it in the air, giving you time to place your next hit strategically. Every hit will cause the ball to gain more speed, making it harder to keep track of, dodge, and hit.

But it turns out that there's WAY MORE STUFF YOU CAN DO THAN THAT. There are six ways of hitting the ball: on the ground, you can angle it up, down, or straight forward, in the air you can angle it up, forward, or spike it to the ground. Spiking the ball automatically doubles the speed, so you can cause the ball to get faster multiplicatively by spiking it over and over again. You can also bunt the ball up, forward, backward, or straight down, giving you options on where you place the ball. Hitting a ball at the same time as your opponent causes you guys to clash and bounce off each other. And with the five characters, each one has their own super move, swing speeds, swing arcs, and hitting angles. This game hits every fighting game requirement in respect to its depth, but at the same time it has that appeal that Divekick has of being super easy to pick up.

The music is amazing in this game, all the tracks are taken from independent music creators, and it sets the entire tone of the game really well. Tracks are intense and fun, matching the frantic gameplay. The sound design isn't shabby either, as the ball increases in speed you hear sonic booms, the hit sounds are really nice and snappy, this game loves to bombard you with its really solid sound design.

The art style is really great, too. Well drawn backgrounds that aren't too busy, but are still dynamic and change as the ball moves faster and faster. The characters are really interesting looking and are animated well, and your moves feel like they have weight behind them.

As for the online, it works beautifully. Lag is completely unnoticable, when it works it works well. I did have occasional disconnection problems, but it was pretty negligable as me and my friends could jump back into the game really easily if anything went wrong and pick up with a fresh round.

The only possible complaint you can levy against this game really is that the content is slightly lacking. With only five characters to choose from and six stages, it might leave you wishing for a little more to play with. But all in all, this game is an incredibly solid mechanical marvel that is great fun with friends. I give this a solid recommendation; there's no reason not to have this in your library.

Lethal League is pretty unique in the world of fighting games. The focus on a single projectile livens up an old genre with pong-like battle mechanics.

Lethal League is also quite easy to pick up. The controls are simple, though there are a number of little tricks to learn, as well as ball trajectories. It will make a great party game, and it's a lot of fun for 2-4 players (the more the merrier IMO, though a good 1 on 1 can be intense).

The solo 'challenge' mode is sufficiently challenging, and if that's not enough, you can also hone your skills against hard bots in versus play. As a solo player, you'll likely spend most of your time in online matches. My experience with online play has been good so far, often feeling as good as the local game.

The art style is a matter of personal preference. I love it. I also love the way visual effects are tied in with the game's core mechanics, with distortion animations playing when the ball breaks certain speeds.

The game's starting roster is small - just 5 characters - but they play quite differently. Some of the differences are obvious, like special attacks, jumps and special movement (like clinging to walls or skateboarding on the ceiling), while other differences are more subtle (like the angles of upwards and downwards strokes). There are rumours of more in the works, and it has been said that new characters will be added to the game in free updates.

With all this in mind, Lethal League is a wonderful gem of a game, perfect for people who want something to play with friends, locally and online, and also great for competitive fighting game players looking for new ways to test their skills and reflexes without memorizing long combos.

Lethal League is like a glorified Pong with a Smash Bros. skin. The basic objective is to knock your opponent(s) out using a ball that you keep knocking back and forth in between each other. Sound simple, yeah? But the catch is the more the ball gets smacked around, the faster it goes. Soon enough it reaches insane speeds to where you can barely keep up with it. The enviornment even changes as the speed gets faster and faster.


The game is played in "Bursts", or rounds, and the ball's speed resets every round. The use of bursts make every round very intense and heart-pounding when the ball reaches the incredible speeds. Dare I say you may even be on the edge of your seat. 


The soundtrack is great, too. Definitely fitting for the game, having nice funky tunes with you. Take a listen sometime.

The characters are pretty unique in their own right. They each have a distinct character design and personality that you can easily recognize. I'm sure you'll find someone you like. Also, each of them have special abilities that have different effects on the ball, such as Candyman's ability to make the ball phase through the walls.

In short, Lethal League is a fast paced, blood pumping action fest that you'll surely get a kick out of. I highly recommend it.

This game is probably the best example of a "Simple yet cathartic" game in recent memory, and its up there with One Finger Death Punch in terms of enjoyable gameplay. It very simple to play, very fun and enjoyable to try out when you have friends over, and the netcode for this game is actually rather impressive, with very few if any noticable drops in input or framerate over multiplayer. Tight controls and a great soundtrack make it worth every penny for me.
