I first played the original "Browser" version of this game a long time ago.
It was insanely fun then, and even more so now that they have an updated version.

The concept is simple: You hit a ball back and forth, trying to knock out your opponent.

The catch? The ball picks up speed. BIG TIME. 
There are 5 characters, and each have their own special abilities and characteristics.
 Some can cling to walls, Double jump, Skate along the ceiling, Wall jump, etc.

They also have a special meter that builds up after 4 sucessful hits, allowing your 
character of choice to unleash their own unique special move.

The animation is fluid and the environments are well done, 
and each stage comes with a pretty sick sound track.

But back to the speed. The game picks up insanely quickly, and you can easily 
lose focus and get frustrated amidst all the chaos. (I had one friend who was turned away from this
game just because it was way too fast paced for him)

It's not for the weak. Haha.

It's easy to master the timing, but I can also see how some people would 
think the game lacks depth beyond just hitting a ball.  

I personally find great satisfaction going up against another person who can keep up.

The matches are extremely exciting, and this is a GREAT party game to play locally.
Hours upon hours of fun if you're competitve, and love getting hyped up during intense moments.

Highly recommended... The price is debatable as far as content goes, but I'm the type of person who
doesn't care too much for that.

Personally i think the game is fantastic to play with friends. I saw videos of people playing it on youtube and loved what i saw. got in and realized... the game is hard, still fun, but hard. the ball goes up to high speeds quicklyso an average game is around 3-4 minutes at 8 lives starting at the default speed. there are a surpriding amount of strategies you can come up with after you figure out the nuances of the characters. my personal favorite is the fact that if you aim up with Switch (the robot skateboarder) the ball goes up and behind you, the hammer girl (Sonata) can change the ball direction with her special, my girlfriend even enjoys playing the aligator (Latch) because she can play "Walligator" by clinging to a wall and swinging until she can grab the ball and shoot it at me point blank. 
all in all it's a good game

a "challenge" mode that reminds me of super smash bros classic 1P mode.
art style isnt much at first but it grows on you
minor connection issues in online multiplayer
local multiplayer as well as online
easy to learn hard to master i would say (a lot of little details that make you better, but arent needed for casual play)
-basics
  - swing (hit ball, ups speed by 1) [aimable]
  - bunt (knock ball up next to hit it gets bonus special meter) [aimable]
        - once bunted the ball will move at a low speed but resume previous speed when hit by a player or hitting the ground
  - parry (hit bunt during a hit to drain your special and knock back nearby players) [must be trying to hit the ball]
  - slam (downward air swing that doubles the speed of the ball)
specials and traits
-candyman
  - ball will teleport to the wall opposite the next wall it collides with keeping speed and direction, refreshed if CM hits it again
  - candyman has no heavy falling
  - candyman has the sharpest slam angle
 - sonata
  - special hits the ball 3 times after release, can reaim the ball at these points
  - has a double jump
 - latch
   - can climb walls
   - largest hitbox
   - special eats the ball, carries it, and releases at speed it was caught
 - switch
   - can scate on walls and cieling (limited time)
   - upward aim goes behind him
   - special is activated as a doublejump, if the ball hits switch during his kickflip the ball is hit by switch (counter)
 - Raptor
  - smallest hitbox
  - can bunt if ball is above him
  - fastest hit
  - special hits the ball twice and can change the direction of the ball on release

It's a shame this game never became a big thing, because it is one of my favorite game concepts that was never fully realized. This game is a wonderful crossover between a sporty type game like tennis, pong, or baseball, with the mechanics of popular fighters like Street Fighter and Mortal Kombat. The game has an excellent electronic soundtrack that perfectly fits the dirt-punk aesthetic the game pulls off with aplomb. The only issue the game has is it is built around being multiplayer, and the game is just not popular enough and the servers not strong enough to really support the game. What I would do if I were you is get this game with a handful of friends so you have someone to play with.  Also, make sure to participate in the little community the game has. They hold tournaments every weekend that allow you to be sure other players are there to play with you.

The online is incredibly good, which is to be expected from GGPO.  4 player games tend to lag/desync a bit, but as long as you are not playing across countries, it handles it well.  1v1 online is nearly perfect from my viewpoint.
Controller support is also good, I have tested 4 different controllers, all of which worked.  Only a few required minimal key binding.
Gameplay itself is of the "simple to pick up, hard to master" variety.  Great for local party/competitive play.  Its fast paced, and has a lot of "epic moments" for all your friends to hype about.
Not much content to be honest, though the game is obviously about multiplayer, and they do have a few modifiers to change things up.  But this is an important note, if you don't have good internet/local friends, do not get this game.  Though I doubt anyone reading this falls under this category.

I personally like the art style, I have heard a lot of people complain about graphics.  I don't really need to review this though, if it looks ugly in the screenshots, you will find it ugly in game.
Boss soundtrack, as in GOOD electronic music, not try hard dubstep.

If my review seems badly written, it is because I am not a writer.  But you can trust me on this, Lethal League is amazing for what it is, and is definitly worth the asking price.  Anyone who is shying away because it is "too simple", there is a lot of depth/mind games to be had in hitting a ball back and forth(as silly as that sounds).  Is it another Nidhogg?  No.  Another Divekick?  ehhh, maybe, depends on whether you hated Divekick for its gameplay or for other reasons.  To me, this seems like a similar concept to Divekick, though better polished, different gameplay mechanic that is more hype because of its faster/more deep nature, and a better presentation.  This game is definitly better than Divekick, but still holds the similar concept of simple but hard to master.

In the end, yes, I do recommend this game.  This game will entertain you and your friends for a long time.

If I have not answered your questions/concerns about this game, leave a comment and I will edit the review.

This game is essentially dodgeball on steroids and it's quite a bit of fun. It is a bit challenging to learn though and gets repetitive fairly quickly, which makes it a bit harder to recommend.

This chaotic multiplayer game puts several characters in a small arena where you smack a ball around while trying not to get hit by said ball, all while the ball gains speed rapidly until it becomes an impossible blur that destroys all in it's path. It's quite chaotic and a lot of fun. Each of the 6 characters also plays slightly differently and has it's own special move, which adds to the chaos, although it does make it a bit harder to learn the game. There are a few different versions of this game to play (free-for-all, teams, and a team variant where you try to hit the other team's goal instead of their players). Unfortunately, this is all there is to this game, and it starts to get repetitive fairly quickly. There is also a single-player challenge mode, but it's very hard and very grindy, so you're unlikely to get much more out of it. It does seem like there is a high skill ceiling, where you could learn the game very well and matches would become much more interesting, but it seems very difficult to reach this, as the game doesn't teach you much about the intricacies of different techniques and mechanics, and the few existing guides that I was able to find were insanely technical and very hard to read. So while this game did give me and my friends some fun, we do tend to go a long time between sessions in this game.

The graphics look decent and the music is quite good. The game also runs well, other than one annoying online multiplayer bug where lobbies would suddenly become impossible to use. Apparently this is a known issue though that simply requires everyone to restart their games, so it wasn't much more than a minor annoyance.

Note that [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/553310/Lethal_League_Blaze/]Lethal League Blaze[/url] was released a few years ago as the sequel to this game. I haven't played it, but some reviews seem to indicate it is better. It's worth looking at before buying this game at least.

[b]TL;DR[/b] This is a decent, chaotic multiplayer game with a fun premise, interesting mechanics, nice graphics, good music, and no bugs outside of one annoying multiplayer issue. However, the game is a bit hard to learn, gets fairly repetitive fairly quickly, and the sequel to this game was released a few years ago, which some reviews indicate is better, so while I'd still recommend this game, I'd probably only get it if you can get it on sale.

-Full Rant-
       I really didnt expect to have to give this game a bad review. It has fun gameplay, nice characters, and overall I found it fun to play alone. But I didnt buy this game to play alone. I wanted to play this game with my friends and family, and since they dont each have a computer of their own I usually stick to buying local multiplayer games. Games like stick fight, move or die, broforce. All indie games. But never before have I had so much trouble playing a multiplayer game in my life than before this game, Not because the game ran terribly or because of some glitches. It was because this game refuses to recognize other controllers and you must manually set up each input for each controller. We didnt know this when we got the game and we wasted 30 minutes checking my computer, my controllers, and my adapters only to realize its the games fault. Never have I seen this before and it makes no sense. If other indie games that likely worked with a similar budget can make seperate inputs immedietly and you only have to connect them to play why couldnt this game.  Ive done my reasearch, and followed any steps I could find and none work. This one detail almost ruins the entire game for me. I shouldnt have to go through all this trouble to play one tiny transition or party game. Seriously it had everything going for it until that happened.

You start off playing it by yourself, against the AI, and although you might think that they're a challange at first, they're actually pretty easy once you get the hang of the basic maneuvers. Then you might mess around with challenge mode, or keep playing against the AI, but sooner or later you will move into the online teriitory, and this can be a scary lace for a newcomer. Quickly, you will learn that the vast majority of recent online players are very good at the game and clearly know what they're doing, so you decide to read up some tips using tha guides on steam. You'll practice over and over, trying your hardest to get good at the game, and you still won't be able to do it. Trust me. I'd call myself a decent player, and I can win some online games, yet there are stilll many, many times where I will be beaten into submission by somebody who really knows their angles like the back of their hand.

Honestly the most fun fighting game I've ever played. The roster is small but there is no "bad" character to play as so it all comes down to personal preference. 

Matchmaking can take a while, and it does have a good 30-40% chance of disconnecting once a match has been made, but this can be remedied by simply restarting the game before looking for another match. Annoying, but honestly worth it if you're invested or feel like getting invested in the game. The playerbase is definitely shrinking but if you're interested in Lethal League Blaze it's entirely worth it to start learning how to play in Lethal League as a good amount of the controls and play styles will most likely transfer over.

Also the music is bangin' and easy to mod if it's not your style. If you're into modding games or want to get into it, this game is super easy to mod, even a modding noob like me was able to have some fun. 

It takes forever to git gud in this game but man once you get there hot damn it's lit my dude. Definitely give it a try!

Lethal League is the oddly fantastic combination of Super Smash Brothers and PONG. Game mechanics are simple, but allow for incredible mindgames and percision. The game also has fantastic visual and musical styling. Honestly couldn't recommend it more.

Let me start out by saying I really dont like arcade style fighter games. This is the first exception I have found.

Lethal league involves hitting a ball into other players. The ball gradually speeds up until it gets to insane high speeds. Unlike most arcade fighter games movement in incredibly important and memorising combos is unnecessary.

You have three skills, hitting the ball, bunting the ball (which stops the balls movement, and a special attack cast by double hitting the hit button after scoring four previous hits on the ball. Each character has a different special attack.

Lethal league is graphically and musically stylish and appealing as well as insanely fun.

-The “arcade mode” of this game (found in Extra > Challenge) is frustrating to play; here’s why:
--Unforgiving: You only get 2 continues before you must retry the mode all over again.
  Preferably, there would be selectable difficulties; the harder the difficulty, the less continues you get
--Length: There is only 6 characters in the game; yet arcade has 10 total matches. 
  This is too many considering the amount of continues you’re allowed to use
--AI: The difficulty curve for the AI is all over the place. 
  This is because the AI can decide on a whim if they will hit the ball or not; they aren’t crippled with a human’s reaction time, and that’s the main issue here. 
  To fix this, I suggest that over the course of a round, as ball volleys and speed increases, you’ll eventually reach a threshold where the AI will allow you to hit them with the ball. 
  This encourages players to use their skills to survive until they reach that point

Now that I've got all that off my chest, I'll be jumping back into Lethal League and playing til I fall asleep on my controller.

As a guy who almost never likes fighting games due to the repetativeness from game to game I find Lethal League such a breath of fresh air and also exitment. Every match is a quick game of reflexes and quick thinking as well as honest strategy against both your opponent(s) and the ball all while still trying to simply predict and track the ball all together. The result is just a fun chaotic match that's quick and easily finished but also intense and engrosing.

I also love the urban style given to the levels and especially the characters. Each character looks unique and cool as well having a nice anime Inspired look that, while risky, paid off and is a perfect example of taking inspiration and not simply copying it.
 The Controls could be slightly quicker but it's a small complaint. I only wish for more characters in the future or maybe simply a sequel. As well I'd also like to see a lot more levels to choose from as they are more just backgrounds. I would like to see some more usage of stage design and maybe the incorporation of obstacles or platforms later down the line.

All in all a terrific and tight game that, while simple and small, has succeeded in what I think it meant to set out to do. To anyone tired of the regular fighting genre or want a really nice cheap 4 person brawler to play with friends I can't think of a better game than Lethal League. Hope to see you on the battle stage.

Lethal League is what would happen if you crossed baseball and dodgeball and then sprinkled in a little bit of Super Smash Bros. Sound crazy? It is a little bit. Allow me to elaborate: The point of Lethal League is to hit the opposing player(s) with the ball without getting hit yourself. The ball starts off slowly, then gains speed through continuous hits and bouncing off of the walls like in Pong or Arkanoid. You can alter the trajectory of your hits by holding the corresponding direction on the joystick when you hit the ball. You can greatly accelerate the ball's speed by jumping in the air and performing a "slam" which rockets the ball back down to the ground. Each of the 6 playable characters in the game have special traits and abilities that can alter the ball's velocity, timing or trajectory to fake out opposing players. The game can be played 1 vs. 1, 2 vs. 2 or free for all style, similar to Smash Bros.

This game also reminds me somewhat of Divekick. The game is very accessible, fun and easy to pick up and play, but I'm a little skeptical about it's long term playerbase retention. I confess I haven't played too much of this game, but I'm suspicious that Lethal League may not have the mechanical depth to keep players coming back for more. Even if it may be somewhat lacking in staying power, Lethal League is still a fun and fast-paced game to pick up and compete with friends or strangers online.

Also of note is the game's awesome soundtrack which falls musically somewhere between Hotline Miami and Jet Set Radio. Like Hotline Miami, the soundtrack is a compilation from several artists that still manages to have a unified sound. Of note is "Scream" by Bignic, "Ordinary Days" by Klaus Veen and "Urabon" by Grillo. I know I've said this before, but I love when game soundtracks have a unique sound like this. Not enough games do that.

Lethal League is a fun, fast-paced and accessible spin on the fighting game genre. I'm a little skeptical about this game's lasting depth, but you should play it yourself to decide where this falls on the scale between novelty and legitimate deep competition. At least I hope you'll be able to agree it has an awesome soundtrack

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

A great indie fighting game that combines the neutral game mechanics of 2d fighting games like street fighter and mortal combat, and the fun factor of the smash brothers series. 

Pros:
A fun experience for people who enjoy fast paced, crazy fighting games.
Relatively cheap, only $20 at the time of posting this.
Great and helpful community.

Cons:
High skill ceiling, many people that are still playing have been for almost a year, and very good players with 400-500+ hours are usually going to be found in online matchmaking
Unranked matchmaking, there's no ELO system of sorts, so you can play anyone from the range of a braindead squirrel, to a winner of 20 tournaments.
Low player count in matchmaking, Lethal League usually does not have a high player count, and they're not always in online matchmaking, so you will sometimes keep matching up against someone you don't want to play against due to them being the only person online who you can play.

Regardless, Lethal League is an incredibly fun and surprisingly complex fighting game, and if you're willing to put in the time and effort to get good, it can be a very self rewarding and fun experience.

Amazing game, probably one of the best multiplayer experiences I've had this past year. It's a projectile fighter, so your aim is to hit the opponent with a projectile (in this case, a ball). Simple, right? Well, you have different ways to hit the ball, directions you can aim it, and specials specific to your character that make each matchup intense. Games can be over in a second once the ball starts moving fast, or even in the first ten seconds if you play right or predict your opponents' moves. There's immense satisfaction in each return, and the game really excites you with the euphoria of good returns mixed with the  rush and fear if your opponent somehow still returns the ball that you just shot at him at 10000 mph. It's sort of similar to in the projectile match between Link and Ganon in the Legend of Zelda, except you die if you screw up once. There's a few game modes that you can switch between, and there are some options to tweak your matches. The options are a little limited, but honestly, the game is so fun that you won't really even need to switch things around to have a great time. Definitely check this out sometime!

With online play: I have had some problems with online battles with friends (game freezing up after stage select, player randomly disconnecting after game), but none of these problems were fixed in under a minute and didn't occur that often. Local play is also supported and is a blast!

Like Super Hexagon-good soundtrack. You get 6 lives and each time you hit the ball, it turns your color and gains speed. If the ball hits one of your opponents while it is your color, they die. Once all of your opponents are out, the match resets, until only one player is left. The character roster is small (6 right now) and I hope they add a bunch more. Up to 4 person free-for-all with one on one options as well. It reminds me of Smash in a way even though its completely different, in that you are constantly timing and lining up juggling, since that's what the entire game revolves around; juggling the ball to gain speed and take your opponents out.

I have had my eye on this game for awhile and finally decided to pick it up while it was on sale.  I am very glad that I did.  It is a projectile-based fighting game where you attempt to smash a ball into your opponent while also avoiding getting hit, kind of like dodgeball on super steroids.  Very fun to play with friends or online.  The online multiplayer is one of the best I've seen.  It runs very smoothly, minus a few hiccups here and there (95% of the timee only happening during a 4-player match).

Each of the characters and stages feel balanced, that is no one seems overly powerful. Every character has a special ability they can use after filling their gauge as well has having unique properties, (Sonata has a double-jump, Latch can cling to walls and strike from wall-cling, ect).  Each character has their own playstyle and most will find one they like over others.

The only real flaw I've seen so far is that the single player/challenge mode is a little boring, but oh well.  Online is more fun anyways. 

Overall I would strongly recommend this game.  It has great gameplay, very fun multiplayer, interesting characters and stages, and a good soundtrack.

There’s an old game design proverb. 

"Adjust a mechanic by doubling or halving it."

Doing so immediately shows it’s relation to the rest of the game. 

Putting that concept in a competitive game is resonant. Call it “gut feeling game design.” Double/half is a mechanic (concept?) people immediately understand. It makes Lethal League easy to teach, usually laying out the groundwork with:

-Hit the other player with the ball. 
-Every time you hit the ball it goes faster.
-Smash the ball to double the speed.

Doubling is the interesting part. It immediately gives strength and weakness. Combine this with bunting ((halvingish speed and giving possession (the ability to win) to all players)) super moves, (break the rules) and ball parry (prevent the ball from being taken) you got mechanics that curate multidimensional bouts. 

If there’s anything off about Lethal League it’s the characters. Outside of Raptor, there isn’t unity in design. 

Lethal League is a fantastic competitive game, and an amazing party starter.

What can only be described as a cross between pong and super smash brothers, this game is now in my top 3 of all time (and I don't just add and subtract games from my list on a whim). I reccomend everyone get this game.

It seems simple at first, just hit the ball to your opponent with dodgeball-esqe rules, and the speed of the ball increases over time. 3 controls; hit, jump and bunt. What most people don't realise until they buy the game and play it for 10 minutes, is that this game has so much depth and strategy. You can perform combos to fill up your special meter, you can parry shots with presice timing to throw your opponent off guard, you can bunt the ball whilst travelling one million pixels per frame to surprise other players, you can blahdy blahdy blah. You get the picture.

There are only 5 characters, and they seem to all be the same at first, but they all have different angles when hitting the ball and they can interact with the environment in different ways. These may seem suttle, but have a large effect on the gameplay. Each character has a special move unique to them also, and when used correctly, can have a devastating effect on your adversarys.

LL is probably the most fun I've had in a decently long while with fighting games, mainly because it's free from the conventional six button input. You and up to 3 other characters swat a ball around a room, picking up speed each time. You can't be hit with the ball if you hit it last so the game quickly turns into finding the angle of the balls path so you can hit it back to the other plays. Considering the speed of the game can rapidly crank up to supersonic the game gets very very hectic very very fast. Controls are simple enough to get the hang of 10 seconds, arrows to move, space to jump, z to swing and x to bunt, but they have enough nuance to warrant a mention. When you swing and hit the ball you can influence its direction by holding up or down to effect its angle. Bunting and then hitting the ball techincally counts as 2 hits, thus it fills your special bar by half. Each character has a special move, unique to them, that can be activated by double tapping the swing key when you hit the ball.  The netcode, the same one from Skullgirls, if I've done my research, is absolutely awesome. Disconnects are rare and there's pretty much no lag. The art style is decent, with each character sporting a completely different build and frame, to easily distinguish them. Each stage is nicely simple, has a unqiue soundtrack, and changes backround once the ball reaches certain speeds. Consider Lethal Leauge HIGHLY recommended. IF you can pick it up for some buddies who are even casually interested in fighting games, LL serves as an excellent "baby's first fighting game".

If you like brawl games (i.e: super smash bros), then this should be an automatic pickup. Great party game, simple yet deep gameplay, and great potential for mindgames and trickery at high levels of play once all the mechanics have been mastered. Be warned however, if you do not live in North America, South America or Europe you might struggle to find a game that isn't laggy if you venture into online multiplayer. If the lag passes a certain threshold, then a crash to the main menu is all but guaranteed. Trying to play too far outside of your continent's peak time (seems to be 8-10pm here in Europe) is an exercise in futility.

Pros:
- Perfect controller support
- Engaging, simple and deep gameplay.
- The community is eager to teach each other tricks, timings, openers, etc, making the learning curve much easier if you ask for help.
- Low skill floor, high skill ceiling.
- Very challenging singleplayer challenge mode.
- Singleplayer, multiplayer and local multiplayer modes.

Cons:
- Lag can become a serious issue if playing with people from a different continent.
- Tutorial leaves a lot to be desired. It misses one of the most important aspects of counter-play (the parry).
- Does not allow you to set a resolution in windowed mode (my biggest gripe with the game).
- Bots lack any non-essential movement (hitting corpses, moving back and forth to add extra visual noise, pre-positioning), making fights against them feel very static compared to players.
- Matchmaking in its current incarnation does not put you into a lobby that has already played a game and has no 2v2 option, making organizing games via steam community chat much better than the "quick match" button.
- No text chat in the lobby, making using the steam community chat even more vital.

Lethal League (LL) is the quintessence of competitive arcade gameplay. Being completely free of over complication, Team Reptile have fortunately channelled the most special elements of the nostalgic games of the golden era, where a sole focus on gameplay has driven design and development. The result being a game with no apparent story, not character progression, and no cheap ways of making you feel as though you should be playing the game, instead it slaps you in the face with a fresh take on Fighters, that is plain and simply, unsullied fun.

The gameplay and structure of LL lends itself perfectly to the resolution of longstanding disagreements (1-on-1 Fights), bouts of personal worth and glory (4 way FFA), and also to bond-building exercises (2-on-2 Team Fights). The beautiful thing about the simple gameplay is it works so well not only in the hectic 4-way FFA, but also in 1-on-1 combat, where the simple mechanics eventually boil down to a game of whits, where you are more trying to force the other player/s to swing at the wrong point, or you are trying to think and act fast enough to catch them off-guard.

That long winded jargon can be distilled down to; this game is perfect for playing with friends, and that is exactly how it should be consumed. This game has one of those qualities where if you get served too hard, you will hate it; so take it in with friends and you will instantly see the gratifying outcome of learning together, while also pulling off some badass manoeuvres resulting in you all squealing like manly Girl Scouts. We have not tried it in Online Play as my internet services would make the game run like an interactive slideshow. But we can safely say that by grabbing a few ales, a few controllers, and huddling around your PC, you will be parting in the finest display of competition I have seen in a video games since Mario Party 64.

Team Reptile have not given this game a huge amount of content, with 5 characters and 6 Levels, BUT, the content in the game is so perfectly polished, I question whether the development team is really as small as they say. We would love to see more playable characters and levels in the future just to give the game that bit of spice, but where it stands now is a testament to where AAA game development falls short in modern game development; where such heavy focus on being the next money making machine makes games lose that…specialness.

From a developer’s standpoint this game has soul, you can feel the love that went into it when you play it. So get it, you won’t be disappointed.

I'm re-doing my review again to give a simple but better explained review. I've bought this game a while ago and at the time it did feel like a really fun game but there's just way more to that. Not too long ago I started playing Lethal League again and this time I actually tried myself to practice and play better. Certainly this was and is the most fun I've had in Lethal League in a while. I now adore it because it feels so exciting playing trying your best and once getting a hang of it you immersed on how intense you can make a match from 0 ball speed to beyond what you can normally handle. I do feel disappointed myself that I have not played this game enough but I'm glad to come back to this game. Unfortunately I've hit some drawbacks/flaws and it's getting to me.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
 - Very simple gameplay and controls, hard to master
 - 7 different levels, with some differences that do impact gameplay nicely
 - 6 playable characters (including 1 secret character) with different abilities, personalities, and even skins to unlock
 - Different game modes to play on each level + customizable game options
 - Challenge mode, as well as Training and How to Play for any newcomers
 - Learning the game play helps you understand your opposition and your kind of play-style so in the end of winning any game mode it feels super rewarding
 - Fantastic graphics and wonderful art style (one of my favorites)
 - Controller support
 - Up to play with 4 players local or online mode
 - One of the best game soundtracks I've heard to this day, absolutely flawless

In fact, this game has some sort of blessing because in my opinion you can play any House, Techno, Hip-Hop, any sort of Electric style music and it fits right in perfectly. It blows me away because I never have much games that I could play my own music too and that would also fit into playing the game. 

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
 - The worst part that gets to me about this game is that after playing it for a while you realize that it lacks content. You start to realize that's there's really not much. It's a huge con because it makes the game feel somewhat barebones.
 - Controller users have the disadvantage of movement as sometimes the moving is not exact
 - Bots on higher difficulties tend to play more unfair as their AI gets too smart for you
 - You just don't get enough XP playing versus against bots. It's just not fair, they put all the big XP rewards to online games and what's worse about it is that this game released 5 years ago so the game alone you can't really find that many players now. You have to search for players outside of the game like in Discord servers and ask them to play with you
 - Dice is rarely spawned on random when playing versus against bots

To end off this review I could say that I wish this game didn't have any drawbacks. It's just too bad no one (of my friends) really play this anymore. Maybe it's time for me to move on now to Lethal League Blaze. Team Reptile however has done a phenomenal job on this game. I adore this game to bits and one huge reason is that it makes me reminisce the great times I've had playing brawl games with my brother and friends. I won't give up on this game because this game has got amazing replayability, and I recommend anyone to play this game. Wonderful game. [spoiler]Also Latch.[/spoiler]
After watching PewDiePie play this on his YT channel, I knew that some day I would own this game. It is still fun after all these years.

I like the concept of this game.  The graphics are great! The animations are clean and smooth.  The game play is fun for a bit, but I feel like I am missing something while playing.  The game play never really does get more complex as you play into it.  By that, I mean you whack a ball back and forth to each other and it gets faster... so pong?  The music is odd and gets annoying after a while.   Also, I can only listen to Candyman screaming "Dammit! Dammit! Dammit!" for only so long before I want to mute the speakers.  I see where they were going with this game, but it could use more characters, more stages and some power-ups to mix it up a bit.  I'm glad I bought this game when it was on sale, if I had paid full price for it,  I would've been bummed.

Pong meets Super Smash Bros in a fast-paced and adrenaline-packed fashion.

You do not know fear until you've seen (or rather, not seen) the ball travel faster than the speed of sound.

But, like Pong and Super Smash Bros, you're going to want this for the local multiplayer more than anything else (although online play is available).

Lethal League is a brilliant fighting game with pong-like elements in it. However, it adds some new elements to the pong formula, such as moving characters, bunting, hit-lag, and directional hits. The game's mechanics are as solid as its soundtrack, which is pretty damn ace too. Including tracks from such artists and Zeroscar and bignic, the soundtrack reminds me of Jet Set Radio's in terms of quality. The only problem I've had so far is trying to encounter players on quick match, though it is far from impossible. Even then, if you have a friend (who has friends amirite) or two, you can play together either locally or via Steam, so you don't need to rely on quick match. All in all, Lethal League is a solid game and merits the price tag.

Hands down the best couch multiplayer game on Steam. It may even be more successful than Smash Bros. at blending the line between fighting game and party game, as the insane flash and hype lives right alongside the fluid, intuitive controls and deep combat mechanics. There is no need to include tons of items and random stage hazards to even the playing field because the core mechanic is so simple to pick up and learn that within just a few games even your friend who says they hate fighting games will be slugging with the best of them. 

This is all wrapped up in a crisp, clean pixel art style with a great cast of characters that anyone can pick a favorite from and an insanely catchy soundtrack that will have you picking stages based purely on the song that plays on it.

The only actual downside to this game is a complete lack of an online community, which is an absolute shame. It is pretty much impossible to connect to anyone to play online, which means if you aren't lucky enough to have a group to play this consistently, the AI vs mode and the challenge mode won't tide you over for long. All I can do is add another glowing review to the pile and hope enough people pick it up one day.

The first time after getting my eardrums blown by the excessively loud menu music I was thrilled to see that I could use any generic usb controller I saw fit and remap it at will, this was nice, the next 30 minutes were spent trying to get a game to consistently work, easily 50% of the time when trying to play with 2 friends (I bought a 4 pack, good to see I can't refund it) the game would fail to connect and we'd have to re-invite eachother all over again. Insanely good competetive game. Has a little bit of a steep learning curve but once you start to get over it you suddenly realize the immense amount of depth the game has. It's insanely fast paced with a unique concept, and has a very interesting mixup-centered metagame that encourages insane plays that require you to think outside the box.

Unfortunately I can't reccomend it fully for a few reasons (but I still love the game very much):
- They just recently announced a sequel, Lethal League Blaze, to come out in 2018. The game looks to be essentially an upgrade to this game, meaning if you might as well wait for the sequel to come out rather than spend money on this game.
- The community is essentially dead. Netcode can be laggy and not a lot of people actively queue: I waited for a game for 20 minutes before giving up yesterday. When the sequel comes out, I suspect people will move to it, leaving this game even dead-er.

If neither of these things bother you (perhaps you're more interested in going to local tournaments or playing with friends like I often do), I absolutely reccomend this game.

[h1]The game itself is very fun, but performance is a serious issue.[/h1]

Lethal League consists of hitting a ball back and forth in order to (hopefully) hit and kill your opponent. Now, it gets much more complex than just this, with parries, clashes, bunts, smashes, and even specials being thrown into the mix, but the basic premise is always the same; hit the ball. You can play with up to 4 people, online or on local, and that's where this game really shines. It's extremely fun to play with friends, due to the easy-to-learn nature of the game, and how hectic and intense the matches can be. If you have a few friends that are willing to play, you're going to have a great time. Even with only a single friend, this game can be a blast. Most people complain about the online multiplayer, as it can be pretty difficult to find a match, with wait times of 5+ minutes just to find one. Don't let this discourage you, however, because the weekends usually boost the playerbase and if you find a match with someone, they'll usually play with you 20 games in a row, so you don't have to go looking for another player again. Sometimes you'll get matched up with a really laggy player, but this is as simple as quitting out and looking for another match. It does happen, but when it does, it's not that big of a deal.

The gameplay itself is very enjoyable, and I can see myself playing this for hundreds of hours. Contrary to what it looks like at first, every single character is unique and different. Even something as simple as the angles they hit the ball at or their hitbox size is different. Every single one of them is properly balanced, with none of them being "the best." The only thing that determines their worth is the person playing them. Any character can beat any character. One of the main turnoffs is the lack of characters, with there only being 6 total to play as (excluding doombox.) But unlike most games, I see this as a good thing. This is due to the fact that all the characters have completely different feels to them, and with only 6 to choose, it allows players to actually learn their moves and develop strategies for each. More than 10 characters would be terrible for this game, because then it would be impossible to memorize all of their moves. And, unlike most other fighting games, there really aren't any "combos" that can be abused over and over again. Any ball can be hit if you're smart enough to know where to stand, or you know how to counter it. There are a few advanced concepts, as I mentioned above, but once you learn those, it's just getting to learn the ball and develop better strategies. If you ever want to switch things up, they do have a few things you can change, including a points mode, different types of balls, and even the ability to turn off ball tagging (making it so you can kill yourself with your own ball,) but generally the default mode is fun enough to not need anything added to it, and it's the most commonly accepted mode online. One of my favorite things about this game is how fast you can get playing, instead of waiting. Within 30 seconds, you can start a match, and within 4 minutes you can be done with one. If you are strapped for time, this will have you covered. Conclusion; you will not get bored of this game if you care enough to learn how to play. 

The soundtrack is awesome. It sounds great and perfectly fits the exciting, fast paced action that usually occurs. It isn't just background music either; most of the tracks are pretty active, and can help build up the excitement. Unfortunately, there is only a very small selection of songs, with there only being one for each stage and then a few extras. 

The perfomance is the downfall of this game. Everything about this game is perfectly fine, but the performance is absolutely god-awful. It actually isn't a demanding game at all; all of the art is somewhat pixellated, and barely anything warrants lag in any way. If you're worried about your older machine not being able to handle it, don't. It will work. The issue lies in the online aspect of the game. The game experiences no perfomance drops when doing local games or bots, but everything else has severe issues. For one, the game can randomly lag in the middle of games that have pretty decent ping. This is unacceptable in a game that has such a focus on timing and precision. There is also a severe issue with games of more than 2 players. When you look online for match, it automatically pairs you up with one other person, so all online matches you play (that I've come across, at least) are 1v1's. Any lag in a 1v1 is usually the result of the other person, not the game. However, this is not the same with a 3 player or 4 player match. Since Lethal League uses P2P connections, any players that lag the game slow down everybody else. This means that one person can slow down the entire game. There is also a crippling bug as of 6/18/17 that still hasn't been fixed for almost 9 months. When playing 3 or 4 player matches, the game can disconnect and prevent the match from starting. After this happens, every single person that has disconnected has to reload the entire game all over again. If you don't, the disconnection will continue to happen until you reload. This happens roughly once every third match for my friends and I, and it completely ruins the game. Just to play around 10 matches you have to reload 3 times. I really don't know why this hasn't been patched yet.

All in all, this game is pretty awesome. It requires a lot of skill, and it really stresses the importance of timing and precision. However, the frequent lag, crashes, and overall issues this game has can ruin the experience. If you have friends that are willing to buy it, or if you frequently play games on a local machine, I would definitely recommend it. A word of advice, though; wait for a sale. $14 is a lot for a game that only really consists of a small amount of content. So, yes, I would recommend this game to a friend.

It's been a long, long time since I wrote my joke, hype fueled review of Lethal League.

I figured I go back and actually update this review with something serious now that I've poured my heart and soul into the game.

Lethal League at its core is one of the funniest fighting games I've ever played, and to this day I have no found any other fighting game that could top it. Doesn't matter if its Street Fighter, Tekken, Marvel, or hell even Capcom Vs SNK. No game I've played since has gotten anywhere near the same feeling I get playing Lethal League.

Starting out, Lethal League was a bumpy ride of glitches, crashes, and other little oddities that slowly matured into a stable game, even as the player population continued to drop. A very high skill cieling game where every character is viable and the only limit to what you could do with any one character was your skill level.

It's an excellent party game, especially when playing locally with friends. And it's music and visual style really bring the characters and action to life as you're smashing super sonic balls back and forth on aesthetically pleasing stages, all while getting caught up in the excitement. 

With Lethal League Blaze coming in 2018, I feel like anyone who hasn't gotten a chance to play Lethal League should definitely pick it up on PC or Xbox 1(If console is also your thing) and give this wonderful game some love!

After playing the game significantly more, this is a re-review of this game, as my opinions have changed since my initial review.

Lethal League is basically Dragonball Z Death Ping Pong Dodge Ball. And it's an absolute blast. It's such a unique idea, and it's executed brilliantly. Up to 4 players, with 6 characters to choose from, are plopped in one of many stages with varying height and width (which matters for reasons I'll get to in a moment). There is a small ball, and you hit the ball to tag it as yours - making you invulnerable to it while it's still tagged by you, and deadly to any others it hits. That's the core of the game.

Now there are various ways to hit the ball. A neutral hit (any hit made while not moving sideways in the air) can hit the ball up, forward, or down. It can also be charged, and if you hit the ball fully charged, it reduces the hit lag, more on that in a moment, and also doubles the speed of the ball. You can also SMASH the ball - which happens if you are moving sideways in the air while you swing. This hits the ball downwards and doubles the speed of the ball. Lastly, you can bunt the ball upwards or downwards, completely fixing the speed of the ball to a slow pace until it's either hit, or hits a wall. Hitting a bunted ball adds 2 bars to the Special Meter, which is filled at 4 bars. Bunting removes most of the hitlag off of any swing, no matter what speed.

As the ball gets faster, the hitlag increases. The Hitlag is basically the amount of time freeze there is when you hit the ball.Hitlag is generally bad - as when the hitlag is high, you're stuck hitting a ball while the opponent can set up a counter swing, if they can predict the angle. This makes SMASHing dangerous, as it only goes in one direction. As such, Bunting and Charge Swings are essential to give your opponent no time to react to the ball. 

One more thing. While in hitlag, you can use your entire special meter to produce a small shield around the ball for a split second. If the enemy hits this shield, they are stunned and sent in the direction your ball will go - it's almost always a confirmed kill. This is helpful if you can predict an enemy is going to try to hit the ball as soon as it leaves your swing. It's also possible to use it on a ball you're both about to hit at the same time - if you hit it first and parry at the same time, they will probably hit the shield and die.

Characters:

There are 6 characters, all of which have unique characteristics and one unique special ability. Special Abilities can be activated by swinging while in hitlag. Some are better than others, but I don't think any are bad. For example, Raptors special hits the ball a second time, removes most hitlag, and allows you to change to any of six directions for the ball, even in a Smash. Candymans special sends the ball through a portal in the nearest wall, coming out the opposite side of the stage. 

Every character also just plays slightly differently. Each character sends the ball at different angles for every type of swing, and have different movement speeds and mobility abilities. Latch can climb up walls and stick onto them, Sonata has a double jump, and Candyman just has a very very high jump. This can possibly give you an edge depending on the stage. 

My Actual Critical Opinion

Lethal League is well made. It's mechanics work exactly as they intended, and it all fits together very well, creating a very well balanced game that is consistently fun. However, that fun is somewhat ruined if you're trying to play online, sometimes. The game's playerbase is very small now. It will take long queue times to find matches, 5 minutes if you're very lucky. I've waited 15 minutes many times. If you get in a game, it's likely with someone with high ping, or if not that, someone who is very dedicated to this game and infinitely better than you. Still, I think it's worth playing online if you can contend with the more medium-level players.

If you have friends who are also interested in this game, I recommend you get it. It's a very fun party game, or off game to play a few rounds in.

If I have ANY criticism for the mechanics, it's the parry system. Namingly, it's a little too powerful. There's very little inscentive to approach someone if they are ready to parry at a moments notice - thus it's almost always a better option to just predict the angle and hope for the best. This is being fixed in the sequel game, Lethal League Blaze - in which there is a counter to the parry, but that game is not out yet. So for now, you have to deal with parry's kinda ruining the fun sometimes. But that is a minor gripe.

Conclusion:

Lethal League is a great game. Amazing, in fact. You should play it. I wouldn't personally buy it at full price, but if it goes on sale, I'd buy it again in a heartbeat. The game got me to love it enough to confirm I will buy the sequel, whenever that comes out. It's worth the money.

Almost super smash bros, almost pong, this game is an incredibly unique approach to couch competitive games. The basic controls and simple design makes it easy for anyone to pick up a controller and understand what is going on. That being said, most of the time, you and your friends have NO IDEA what is going on unless you have played for countless hours. That confusion  creates the kind of lighthearted antics you would get from a game like smash. Even though it is easy to understand, that does not mean it is shallow in depth. There are rather advanced things you can do with angles, and hit lag, specials, and parries. This game can get rather intense.

Lethal League is one of my absolute favorite games, despite my low game time, mainly due to having nobody to play against besides AI. I look forward to the sequel and having people to play against!

Overall, the game is very fun, the pricing is slightly steep, but it could be a lot worse.

For starters, I'll focus on the single player aspect of the game. So you have your standard bot mode where you just battle it out with bots, the bots can be pretty derpy at times especially the lower leveled ones, but they are useful for training. Last thing you want to do Is dive straight into multiplayer. Then you have the challenge mode where you go up against progressively harder bots in a variety of contexts, this is pretty good for learning specific character's playstyles and eases you into harder and harder opponents, which I think is a nice touch, there is also a training function which gives you space to knock the ball around and just practice getting a feel for a character.

Onto the multiplayer. Overall there is a pretty cool community out there, but also skilled. Skill is key in this game which is why I warn you not to dive headfirst into multiplayer unless you are familiar with the gamestyle. I suggest you find a character you like and learn that character; each character has there own abilities and angles, so learning those is key. After you've learnt a formidable amount about a character, move onto another if you feel up for it, it will force you to adapt but your skills will sharpen and you'll be able to understand what you're up against.

But yeah, brilliant game, I'd rate it a solid 8.5/10.

Super fun, whacky take on a blend of pong and 2D fighting. Great competition online and indescribably hype playing playing 4 players local too!

I didn't have much issue with lag or anything like that online.

The controls are simple, but, in a similar way to Smash Bros, the mastery of those controls can go on and on. You can really become an expert at your movement and positioning to set yourself apart from the other players. It's not all just goofy, non-sensical mayhem.

The music is great; coherent with the cel-shaded art style.

All-around, a very cleanly polished game in terms of art and mechanics, that ultimately provides a thrilling experience.

I hold a high respect for this game.  It's fresh, completely -oozing- with style and attitude, and the controls and gameplay are tight, responsive, and flexible.   The mood is explosive and raw, the music is absolutely BANGIN', and even the smallest matches - especially your first ones - are hype as hell.  Probably best if you try the game with another newb friend.

If you are a fighting game enthusiast like myself, you'll be pleased to find that there's definitely a limitless skill ceiling and that the small roster means they're fine-tuned to perfection.  Even if you don't plan on getting good, it's fantastic to just learn the game in itself and how each angle and special can be exploited at what times.

Have fun raging when you miss the ball after the first swing and it bounces back to clock you in the head at 8 speeds-an-hour.

It's hard to find games that are playable in local multiplayer, are really easy to pick up, and ALSO have a lot of depth and challenge. Lethal League is pretty simple overall, but is just perfect. Its controls involve just three buttons; not "Divekick" excessive simplicity, but enough that people won't shy away from picking up the third or fourth controller. Even so, there's definitely enough variety of play at work. There's also a great tactile feel to mashing a ball around at each other,

I've been bringing a laptop loaded with this game to a local bar, and people were very quick to pick up on it; several people there are probably better than I'll ever be already. (I still don't know how to do poses as each character!)

(fyi: little playtime on my account because I've hooked it up at a bar, on a laptop that's always offline)

I still cannot believe how quickly this game became such a competitive sport between me and my group of friends. While this game may appear simplistic at first, there's actually a ridiculous amount of depth and strategy to the gameplay. Timing, ball speed, bunting, faking, clashing, differences between upswings and downswings, each character's speed, jump height, hit box, swing box, special move, hit angle, and wall manuevering. If you wanna have a good time with your friends, then play this game. However, I highly recommend controllers
